This is why many philosophers were punished, because they made the idea of salvation and god accessible to everyone, so that they no longer needed to rely on the Church. comment_text: I could fully enjoy this conversation only if Steven Barlett could ask the distinguished guest "How can you say that?" at 01:39:29. So we have no way of considering (?) there are The Italians, The French, The German, The Arabs, The Turks, The Chinese, The Indians and others with intellectual traditions deeply ingrained in the planet Earth's history? Oh of course there are all these people, Sebastian Bach, Beethoven, Da Vinci, Lao Tse, Shakespeare, Tolstoy, Callas, Sinan, Meyers the Violinist.. but the guest was concentrating on traditions energized by the notion of God.. but then Steven Barlett could ask "How can you say that?" again when the guest defined Western Civilization as an "overlap" of Greek, Roman and Judaic traditions. There are two main traditions that do definitely not overlap: The Greco-Roman as opposed to the Judeo-Christian. How can I say that? I say that because all the music comes from the clashes, the conflicts as well as those bilaterally convenient tolerations between these two traditions. They do not overlap dear Dr. Peterson; they live on side by side, if at least the interview is meant to allow a conclusion of this kind. I do appreciate Dr. Peterson when he is a "seer" as a psychologist. Very strong, indeed.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: It was interesting to hear Peterson say that he was intentional about establishing his three income streams and that allowed him to speak his mind. But this is coming from an incredibly privileged position. Most people don't have those options on the table. Ultimately, U of T allowed him to pursue all of these things. (Tax payers and university donors) Normally, academics are allowed about 10% of their time for outside revenue generating work. Clearly, Peterson was taking much more than 10% of his time doing that. Most people in the world are not university professors and so are expected to devote 100% of their work time to their employer. Then, add a home and children, where would the average person find the time for three revenue streams? Well, maybe they could work all the time and be (potentially and likely) miserable. And those who are professors dedicate most of their time to the academic endeavor. Moreover, if Peterson was so successful in his choices, how did he get so addicted that he ended up in a medically induced coma in Russia?

comment_text: What he was saying about chatbots leads me to something Paul Washer says about a mate who is not fully 'compatible.' You need a partner who challenges your SIN. If they just do and say everything you want, then they are just an extension of your hedonism. If you smoke crack and have a partner who smokes crack, then you will be stuck in it longer (though a non crack smoker is unlikely to find a crack smoker attractive or viable). If you have road rage, and a short temper, you need a partner who's a calm driver and slow to anger. If they have other sin you need to not have it. With chat bots, they can flatter you and harden you in sin by never challenging you. It's like finding a partner to just cuddle on the sofa to smoke weed. It is pleasurable but you never grow. Often such challenging people get rejected in the dating stage by someone who just wants what they want to hear. It's just the difference between God who challenges sin, and my own 'god' who agrees with everything I want. God is going to ask me to behave in ways I fundamentally do not want to, but that's good, because those are areas of my life that need adjustment.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: @TheDiaryOfACEO  It was interesting to hear you say that you are struggling with marriage as well as with God. This makes sense since marriage was designed as a vehicle to demonstrate on earth how relationship with God works. First a covenant is established in which they forsake an old life and enter into a new life in which each is willing to lay down their life for the other. Then, since they are now one instead of two, they walk in love and an intimate knowledge of each other that then produces a new life... a new human  being. Spiritually, we can only know God when we enter into a covenant relationship with him. God has come in the flesh in the person of Christ and laid down his life for us and we give our life to him in return (trusting the one who gave himself for us; see Galatians 2) we are made one by the Spirit of God. This produces a deep,  personal, experiential knowledge of God and a loving relationship with Him, That then produces spiritual life in us and we are able to bear spiritual fruit (see Galatians 5-6) that formerly we were unable to. We were made to be a dwelling place for spiritual life, love, joy and peace, since we are made in God's image. But because our relationship with God was broken when we rejected Him, we no longer produce spiritual life, but spiritual death and separation. But God came down in the person of Jesus to live that spiritually full life physically as a human and also satisfy the debt/sentence for our crimes; so that, if we trust Him enough to enter into a covenant relationship with Him, His full payment now satisfies our debt and the eternal that life Ge has He now shares with us... and now we live a full spiritual life because we are joined together with Him. This loving, intimate, personal, covenant relationship with God in Jesus Christ is true Life, spiritual life... and it is eternal.

Lost all credibility as a person with integrity for me. A pity. If he'd said, yeah he's a textbook narcissist, but I'm voting for him as I think he's the better representative for me, at least that would be honest. And it's not just him.... All these podcast guys backed Trump....  watching them all starting to back pedal pretending they didn't really think he was such a great guy, actually. 🤨 🙄  Anyway.... I do like listening to a lot of Peterson's ideas and I've followed his stuff for years. He's just disappointing as a person.

comment_text: On the topic of p*rn, the real experience and the digital counterfeit feel completely different. I use p*rn as a tool to regulate my libido and keep it essentially turned off so I can focus important things like work and building real relationships. I still am highly motivated to see and experience the real thing. It's like comparing splenda to sugar. Sure they are both sweet, but splenda is fake, doesn't taste the same, a little too sweet (not in a good way), and leaves you with a bad after-taste. Sugar by contrast is the perfect amount of sweet, is the real deal, tastes perfect, and you only feel bad if you have way too much. comment_text:
I appreciate all of Jordans work and how he has helped so many people, however…

There are just too many holes in the ‘God’ story.

I’ll start with a general question.

Why is it that heaven was/is always portrayed as being in the clouds? Heaven up and Hell down.
Why are there tens of thousands of paintings of God in the clouds, angels in the clouds etc.?

I think those paintings exist because humans hadn’t been through the clouds yet.
Planes hadn’t been invented, to see that actually, there is nothing in the clouds. Nothing.

So they made it up. They didn’t know that there was nothing there (which is fair enough), but they made it up. Pulled it out of thin air as it were.

So here’s the question, if this fundamental part of religion is made up then what else did they make up?

Yeah, great stories. The bible helps so many people live well, so all good, but lets’ not forget that a large part, if not all of the god story is simply made up. 

There absolutely could be a god, but come on.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
I think I commented thus here already. Marriage IS living together, that's what people have done forever. 

The reasons people who have ceremonies before living together may stay together longer could ephasize belongin to religious or cultural groups that emphasize couples staying together, somtimes making laws about it or using laws that make legal separation difficult or punative. It's also the case tha many times these celebrations cost money, and I think whereas an increase in money and affluence somehwat lowers divirce rates (or say high education status), it's just as true that money and influence can be used to cover up indiscretions. I think of a number of wealthy women married to wealthy men who perhaps expect/allow their husbands to cheat. Class and such mean more to some people. Now, for a poor person, that's just not the case. A woman these days may not be getting very much from her husband other than sincere affection and love, which would be threatened by the man being with someone else.

And again, when it comes to ceremony or state licenses (which are new to history), we're talking about categories of people: People who are "law abiding" versus those who are marginalized or social outliers. A number of those folks are going to be the kinds of people with lower moral character, and the rest probably live such stressful lives, not due to moral character per se, but that their for separation is higher. 

I like Jordan Peterson but I believ he's absolutely wrong about marriage being entered into by vow. It's living together. He probably thinks it should be a public vow. But anyway, I just totally disagree and think the basic meaing of marriage is livin together and that it's deeply disrespectful, even though many or most couples do not believe living together is marriage, but of the poor and most simple societies since the beginning of time, including Adam an Eve who took no vows.
author: @Patricia-t4j3x

comment_text: I met my husband when we were both 15, started dating at 16 and instantly knew we would spend the rest of our lives together. I think knowing we were both in it for the long haul allowed us to live together beforehand and it still be successful. We moved in together at 21 (I didn't want to live together during university), proposed at 24, then got married at 25 and are currently pregnant with our first at 27. We ALWAYS knew we would get married so it was never in our minds that we had an easy way out. Although, I am sure we are apart of the few who did work out. I am not sure I would have gotten married sooner due to financial issues, and I don't think I could wait any longer to have lived together. I think everyone's lives require certain things to make their marriage work but as long as both individuals are committed to each other, it'll work out.

comment_text: The reason divorce rates are higher for people who live together before they marry is NOT because they lived together. You’re looking at correlation, not causation. The other correlation is the people who don’t live together first are people who come from very religious families, where the social costs of divorce is much higher, so regardless of whether they are happy in their marriage, they will stay in it because there is a religious threat to their identity within their community. So yes, people who live together first tend to be less religious, and more capable of getting divorced if their relationship is going poorly.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: 1:52:00 my take is the two are at odds. The concept of thinking beyond the current moment is something that humans are really the only animal that displays this behavior. This is why the question about your dog's God feels so nonsensical. All other animals follow only the programming born out of thousands of generations of perfecting for the current environment. Humans have these same instincts. Animalistic, what is best in the current moment. The same hedonism you spoke of earlier. Our projection of long-term thinking is our projection of godliness. Where these two meet is reality. Each generation will respond to the current situation based on these competing stimuli. When things are bad and short-term strategies for work, child rearing, and mating fail, long-term thinking prevails. It is no wonder we see religions grow in these times. During "good times," the "devil" (i.e., our animal instincts) are more prevalent. Women look for men with resources over knowledge and potential. Men respond by trying to get rich quickly. Long-term relationships seem pointless. After all, the best case for a long-term spouse is the fact that in bad times, your pain will be lessened. If you have never known a bad time, you assume this will go on forever. The problem, of course, is that the more people who act on animalistic instincts, the less effective short-term thinking becomes. The more a society seems godless and the more being godly looks appealing. By the way, we are reaching that point now. The solution to our current predicament is more long-term thinking over hedonism. Whether or not you think long-term thinking is divine and past through us by God, or whether you believe it was some glitch in chimp DNA that made their brains completely different than every other animal ever is really immaterial. The outcome is the same either way. The problem is, most humans don't care to consider any of this. They need a religion to encourage them to think beyond the next 5 minutes with a built-in system of consequences.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
45:52 

Jordan B. Peterson argues that women "choose" men based on evolutionary biology, but this doesn’t hold up fully in reality. If biology ruled, women would consistently choose stable, reliable men who offer long-term security. Instead, many are drawn to chaotic, dominant, or dangerous men — leading to unstable relationships and self-destructive outcomes.

Historically, men controlled mate selection through power and resources, while women developed indirect strategies like flirting to influence male choice.

Today, women have more freedom in the dating market but often still gravitate toward the "bad boy" archetype, contradicting evolutionary logic.

Here’s the reality:
The stable man, overlooked in youth, wins over time. By his 30s and beyond, with financial and emotional maturity, he now chooses.
Many women, conditioned by ruthless or competitive environments, can no longer identify real stability, misreading calmness as weakness.
Men don’t avoid "strong women" out of fear. They pass them over because they often project arrogance or emotional unavailability — traits that mature men, who now have options, simply aren’t interested in tolerating.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
The problem with living together before marriage is that you are exponentially less likely to give up on your relationship and instead work trough each-others bad habits if you are married. Ending a marriage is a lot more effort and takes a lot more of an emotional toll on you so it is easier and better to work things out.

However if you are just dating, especially if one of you is living in your partners home and has no real right to stay there beyond a flimsy rental agreement and your partners love for you (say they can pay the bills on their own and you aren't necessary for their living situation to stay the same), you will get your ass kicked out once or twice of a dumb argument.

It's tough for sure but it also shows you the real, raw truth of who you are planning to spend your life with. You will find out how they treat you when you are sick and can't contribute to the household. You will also find out if they are ungrateful twats that believe you going out of your way with nice home cooked meals and acts of service is the bare minimum and needs no thanks.

There are many more benefits to living together in my opinion, especially because people can fake a kind and compassionate persona as long as they aren't ever required to care for you beyond some flowers and a night out.

Especially for women i think it is incredibly important to know how your partner treats you, even more so if you are entering a relationship with traditional roles. So many men treat their "housewife" girlfriends like an object because they don't see the person behind their fantasies. You never want to end up in a situation where you got married, moved out to another state or even country and then find yourself with a thankless husband that expects you to sit trough countless berating lectures because you salted the salmon too much for his tastes, then goes cold when you don't want to sleep with him after. 

My boyfriend is truly, truly lovely but in the two years we lived together he has shown those exact patterns himself, kicked me out or threatened to do so numerous times because he was fed up by me trying to have a conversation where i criticize his negative behavior instead of it being the other way around and we are still working trough those cycles of anger and hurt to this day. It is an uphill battle but i cannot imagine being stuck in a marriage with a person that wouldn't be emotionally mature enough to at least try to change. 

Please be ready for war when you move in together because it is inevitably going to happen once you both let your true, unrestrained and damaged souls collide. But also prepare to sit in that anger as often as it is necessary and try to come out on top, together at that. Arguments are always a loss to your relationship once one person has "won" and the other has been "defeated". 

My one singular piece of advice that i feel like needs to be heard is : Never try to be "correct" or "right" in arguments about how your partner is feeling. Their perception of your treatment towards them might be distorted but it is real. Instead of telling them how they are wrong in their own perception, show them that you aren't trying or ever tried to hurt them. Express that you will not do it again and find a solution to the core problem instead of fighting them until they give up. You can say what you feel so they have a chance to see your side as well. But Your side is your side, their side is theirs and the truth is never represented in either one of them. A relationship is not math, it's more like a riddle. video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: It's why it is so important to not rush into a committed relationship and it's why many couple's aren't happy in their relationships and  how many are miserable together. Happiness, contentment, satisfaction and certainty doesn't exist in an unhappy relationship, and if it's a married couple, you can predict probably that it isn't going to improve. The ONLY  way that it would improve is someone will have to sacrifice, meaning that whatever it is that one person doesn't like about the other, that thing that wasn't obvious in the a short "dating" stage, whatever that particular thing is, in order to be the happiest that you can be in an unhappy relationship will require some communication first, to bring the issue to the table, whatever it may be, it's different for every couple, but it will have to be discussed, the person who has problem with something that the other does, or it may be something that the other person believes, something new or that thing that wasn't revealed in the dating stage. The person will have to make it known to the person who is doing it and that is a very hard thing to do , to have a calm mutually agreed discussion without it becoming an argument, where they may feel they're character is being attacked and judged. It's a very delicate thing and has to be done in a delicate way. It must be done in such a way that the person doesn't feel they are being attacked, or judged. What usually happens is the person will think the person who "suddenly" has a problem with them is trying to change them and this my dear friends is when you know if it's going to have a good outcome, where there is a resolution to an obvious issue. It can go two ways, they discuss whatever the issue is, making the other person aware that they have an issue and it will either be discussed and understood why the person has an issue and if it hasn't blown up and turned into someone feeling attacked and doesn't like that their partner all of a sudden has an issue with them, which is probably how most discussions end up, without any resolution and nothing changes, not as far as an issue being solved goes. What does change however is a brand new bitterness and hurt feelings or anger from the person who felt attacked, and the person who wanted to discuss and resolve an issue, that person feels like their feelings aren't important to the other person. It's just a couple who didn't take the time to learn about each other before vowing a life of love and honoring one another as God as their witness.  The only way to be happy in marriage or committed relationship is to be able to sacrifice. If my spouse has a problem with me, I will have to either change what they don't like about me, but not just that, I will have to be ok with changing whatever it is they don't like and to make sure I don't do it again and just as important, I can't have a problem with doing it. If I have a problem with changing something about myself that my partner doesn't like, I cannot be bitter about it, not if I agreed to stop doing it, otherwise resentment is there and resentment grows, and it will be an unhealthy relationship affecting every person around them, especially children, there no way that it won't affect them. Basically when there is an issue, it will have to be decided by both mutually to either live with the issue because the person tells you that they can not change or stop whatever you are having an issue with, and if they cannot, you will have to be either ok with it, accept whatever it is and for it to not be an issue in the future, or if it's an issue that may be something that you can't accept to be ok with, then you'd have a decision to make. As harsh as it seems, but to stay and nothing to change, is going to be years living in a miserable marriage, affecting all involved. On the other hand, if the person who is doing the thing that their partner doesn't approve of or like, that person will either have to choose to stop doing the thing and to be ok with it, and to not be bitter about their decision to stop doing it. You cant agree to it without being able to be ok doing it and to not let it grow into resentment later, not when it was a mutual discussion and a resolution was agreed on. If it is something that the person says they wont or cant stop doing, a sacrifice they are not willing to make, then they will have to live with the consequence that maybe it isn't something the spouse can sacrifice and live with where nothing changes. It comes down to sacrificing. Giving up something to have something, and in the end, whatever remains is proof of how important or how unimportant it was to each person involved. Sacrifice is a huge part of marriage, to give up something for another person, that's the most unselfish a person can be when it comes to true love, Jesus did it for the entire world and we have a problem doing it for just one person. That will come from not taking their time to know a person, and time does have a way of revealing what is truth and save us from a life of misery, resentments and regret. The best thing to do in life is forgiveness. It isn't simple to live with something we may not like or simple to give up something for another person, but either way it is a sacrifice someone has to decide to make.

comment_text: I'm a big fan of Peterson's work, but as someone who has surrendered and given himself up to God, I chuckle when he says "it's a complicated answer". That's the beauty of believing in God. He gives you the answers. It's the difference between a spiritual framework and a moralistic one, that is, the act of truly believing. That's why we say things like "a leap of faith". You leap towards God with an open heart in a vulnerable act of faith in him. Only then will you get the answers you seek. Only then will these "complicated" questions become clear and simple.
author: @ksok27

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: In light of the final question: JP is a great mind and there is lots to learn from his perspective on the world. I may not always fully agree with him, but that does not mean I don’t respect him. And there is a difference between misunderstanding and not understanding. On some occasions I don’t understand where he’s coming from, but I don’t misunderstand what he’s saying. For me there might be a mental step missing that is important to me and apparently not to him, but that’s okay. He is at least very articulate and careful about his words, and usually nuanced where necessary. If you’re looking for a person that is going to give you clear bite-size answers, he’s not your man. If you need food for thought and want to gain something intellectually, he often delivers. There is only one thing that sometimes annoys me, which is that he has the tendency to speak more than to listen. Which is odd, because I’m sure that he is very capable of it. The man spent decades in clinical practice, so he definitely knows how to let people formulate their thoughts before chipping in. Another thing I liked about the interview was that it pretty much kept away from politics. I don’t dislike politics, but there is enough of that on YouTube already. And it perfectly showcases Steven’s interviewing skills. So yeah, thumbs up for this episode of DOAC 👍
author: @edwindijk2877

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
49:06 Thank you for the interview. I am responding to your question before listening to Jordan on the topic of reserving sexuality for the institution of marriage. This is how I lived my life as a young man. The benefits to the individual are based in Self Regulation:
1) Increased Self Discipline
2) Increased ability to Pair Bond
3) Increased Self Confidence with age
4) Supreme BS Meter
5) Supreme Filter of bad women
6) Increased Emotional Stability
7) No unplanned pregnancy 
8) No diseases
9) Never worn a condom in my life, only know natural feeling

Benefit to couples is an exponential increase of the aforementioned along with:
1) Highly Stable Relationship
2) Deeper Pair Bonding
3) No comparison to others
4) Satisfaction with partner because there is no competing memory
5) No diseases beyond genetics
6) Children born into a stable home

Benefits to society:
1) Reduced rates of disease
2) Emotionally balanced people
3) Reduction in wayward youth
4) Increased self regulation
5) Reduced crime rates
6) Economic Stability through reduced government support of freeloaders

The choice to follow such a life is challenging but incredibly rewarding. It requires deliberate effort on all parties and deep social investment. These are typically religious communities and are highly stable.

Last but not least- the dating environment is a blast! Everyone’s expectations are the same. It is socially acceptable to be dating multiple people at one time because there is no sex involved. Multiple dates with multiple people back to back to back. People that likely all know each other to one degree or another. Couples that form are accepted and there are few hard feelings that last long. Coupling is expected, spoils to the victor. Loser gets better at dating. 

Dating in this manner during my youth was incredibly frustrating and rewarding at the same time. It made me who I am today and I look back on it with great fondness. I dated a lot of women and had safe fun!

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
As someone who studies “The Human Condition” as a historian of religion, I was captivated when asked what fictional character he would identify himself as, he answered authentically: Bugs Bunny - the “trickster”.  I am really interested in how ancient religions morphed and coalesced into  large tropes - ie almost cliche labels of Christianity/Judaism/Islam/Hinduism/Buddhism/etc. as being a definition of belief/ritual/dogma that is universal when there are so many different dogmas/rituals/etc. within each of those enormous “categories.”  In fact, I would argue that the types or aspects of “divinity” as the terms of a polytheistic religion allow for those PERSONALITY traits we each express.  The trickster aspects in every culture across the ancient/still polytheistic religions is crucial for a society; it dances along the edge of chaos and challenges others in a social group/culture to let go of the illusion of control.  Exs: Loki in Norse-Germanic mythology, Hanuman in Northern ancient into modern India/Hinduism the The Coyote in many Native North American theology/“mythology” play a crucial role in “balancing” the chaos.  With the larger homogenized tropes in modern particularly Western or Abrahamic faiths of such particular aspects of survival in a society are made too black and white with the globalization of these religions and  ignore the evolution, metaphor, and allegory of the Hebrew Bible/OT about divinity and decides it (I blame the Ancient Greek philosophers -lol ) must be literal thereby distancing the mind from the body leading to an illusion of good and evil as distinct and ignoring those grey areas that is where life really happens.  He draws on this diversity for his understanding of the human mind in this book as shaped by the language of religions from antiquity that speak in rhyme/metaphor/allegory.  (Note - he states he is drawing from the ancient oral then written tradition of the HebrewBible/OT.  He does not use the very Western and newer books of the NT/the Talmud/the Qu’ran which are influenced/shaped post Classical Greek explosions in rational understandings of divinity.
I am so thrilled to have discovered your podcast and your willingness to explore very diverse, controversial, and uncomfortable parts of “The Human Condition”.   We as a society need your willingness to question and be open to discussing the “ugly” and the beauty of ourselves.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
When orthodox religion is cited to promote their conservative agendas the individual loses credibility.  
I knew that this interview would lean conservatively yet I chose to listen to it in its entirety. 

What I notice is that there is a Protestant bias towards his ideologies.  Ideas like the individual is designed for conquest. And it is framed in such a way which is patriarchal. He also promotes tribalism which creates secularism. This is antithetical to unification.  

He does weave some facts in there in terms of psychological dispositions and Perterson placed judgement on those behaviors. He promotes abstinence and repression of these drives but he does not talk about how repression manifests in destructive ways.

 I hear platitudes with regards to some of the obstacles we face and he does not really grasp the essence of the time we live in. He also transforms the meaning of Nietzsche's Ubermenche to something which suits his purpose and is unfaithful to the philosophical scholarly interpretation.  Also Nietzsche points out that we have used narratives throughout history to divest ourselves of our existential anomie and this behavior is eternally masochistic. 

One thing I can say is that he makes himself vulnerable in the interview and we gain some insight into his reasoning. I give him credit for that courage.

Hard pass on this interview.

14:15 it's interesting to have religious terms be used in a secular sense. i wonder if different words should be created so when you're referring to "god" in a technical sense, people understand you're referring to a greater motive rather than thinking you're referring to some supernatural entity

25:04 i feel like this is a weird take from him tbh. i would choose my kids looking down on me any day of the week if it means they don't need to go hungry. the wellbeing of the people who depend on me comes before any ego i might have
25:13 which is a luxury that people don't always have... if they could just "find another job", most people seem to work a job they hate just bc they don't have any other choice. you would imagine that if it were so easy to simply "find another job", that being able to speak freely wouldn't be the dealbreaker

27:40 this was honestly on my mind when he initially said the thing about "if your job requires you to lie, you should find a different job" lol. "if having your wife requires you to lie, you should find a different wife"

37:29 idk if this is the answer he'd give, but i reckon that the most attractive type of person (at least in terms of men) would be someone who's charismatic, intelligent, a provider (ie rich, if not also powerful), and physically fit. so like, james bond

44:38 that's a really funny and accurate perspective. a woman who's beautiful already makes 90% of men afraid to approach them bc they think she's out of their league, much less beautiful and intelligent. and then add success on top of that, and a woman's tendency to pursue men who are more successful than her, and you have a woman who'd only attract the attention of (and be interested in) the top .1% of men. we're talking like, the elon, zuckerberg, bezos, gates of the world
44:53 feeling "emasculated" is probably another strong reason lol. if she's smart and rich... well that's 2/3's of the man's role in the relationship being taken by the woman. all that's left for him to be is the muscle, and with modern technology and services, you can just buy a can opener or call a mover if you need that sort of help

47:40 i don't think i've ever heard such a straightforward breakdown of people like this lol

49:50 i feel like that is a perfectly reasonable attitude to have tho. being married is a serious commitment, just as spending hundreds of thousands on a car or a house is. you want to know what you're getting into before you commit, and living like you're married is the perfect way to do that. and besides, it's not like anything becomes possible after marriage that wasn't possible before. marriage is just a social construct that describes the commitment between two people who've decided they want to start a family together

50:21 semantics, but technically it's not. that's why divorce is a thing lol, it's the ending of a marriage. marriage is a commitment, not an irreversible transformation

50:40 i feel like the implied logic here becomes "get married asap so you can have sex asap". which, i would be surprised if that somehow results in a more stable marriage than an advance "trial period"

52:20 exactly, there's no material change after getting married. it's not like you can have a child after marriage and you couldn't before

52:28 "do what works" is good for stability, not so much for innovation and growth. i feel like peterson's "tradcon" mentality really shows itself here lol

53:53 this feels like a very spiritual/symbolic way to view something that's ultimately still a secular problem. and maybe that works for some people, but i doubt it's the definitive solution for all people (again, why divorces and single parent families happen. it's not like being married magically makes it impossible to separate)

1:02:15 it's "not supposed to be easy" in terms of finding a mate, perhaps. but modern innovations mean that sex does not necessarily equal mating anymore. which means that you can scratch the sexual gratification itch without compromising the health of the gene pool

1:03:03 watching porn is magnitudes different from experiencing the real thing in person tho... like eventually porn won't cut it anymore and you'll still be desperate
1:04:00 this actually reminds me of an interesting point that twitch streamer asmongold has made before. he's said that ai gfs will be viewed as a disability aid in the future, and based on what jp says here, i'm starting to see the validity of that claim. why would a guy of sound mind and body not be able to attract girls? ai gfs would only be used by guys who have some sort of handicap for whatever reason who struggle to attract girls
1:04:40 exactly what i was thinking of lmfao

1:07:17 porn isn't that deep to me lol. it just gives me smth stimulating to help me get off. if i'm not feeling horny, i don't watch porn. and sometimes i even feel a specific type of horny that porn can't satisfy, so i just resort to fantasizing

1:12:27 i think he meant "sexbots" but his usage of the term "succubi" in place of it is so funny to me. that's exactly how i would imagine some time traveler from the past who comes to the present describing such a concept

1:13:02 it's funny, bc the way he talks about this topic, he clearly thinks of it as dystopic. but for lonely, disenfranchised/alienated men, there is no concept more utopic than the idea of a girl who won't judge him, won't harass him, that he can get along with, who is also attractive and sweet and loving

1:13:22 i wonder what he means by this. is he saying that an ai gf would only serve to satisfy a guy's hedonistic side, and turn him into this sedentary blob or smth? just immediately, i feel like you could apply that argument to a lot of other things that we've just accepted as part of our lives these days. so unless he's approaching this from a "let's not make a bad situation worse" angle, i'm not sure what his point is supposed to be

1:43:43 i don't think they "have" to come from religion/god, necessarily, but it's much easier to say that "god wants you to act this way" than it is to say "acting this way makes you a good person, but otherwise won't change anything about your life"

2:20:51 i think it's good to express your standards for someone, but if they fail to meet those standards, it's also fine not to be too harsh on them. like the "i'm not mad, just disappointed" meme. and sometimes, feeling like you failed to live up to someone else's expectations is equally punishing as them getting mad at you. or at least, it is for me lol

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
No amount of intellectual profundity in this one interview will negate the depravity and despicableness of his past statements and viewpoints. Lest we forget that this is the same man who unequivocally doubled down on calling a model on the cover of Sports Illustrated “not beautiful” for no other reason than she committed the sin of being bigger than her size 0 industry counterparts . Then to come on here with the proverbial cry crocodile tears as regards all the “stressful” & expensive legal battles he’s had to contend with is honestly quite fraudulent, pathetic and morally & intellectually dishonest at best.  

That’s not to say that I don’t agree with him on many subjects. It’s just unfortunate that I have to be extremely vigilante when listening to him so that I make sure his insidiously psychopathic views don’t fly so far under the radar as to be missed and unwittingly absorbed by my subconscious. It’s unfortunate that he has so many view points that undermine him both intellectually & more importantly MORALLY given that we expect our popular philosophers to be somewhat of a compas in society pointing us towards the common good.  

Therefore I urge you all to be attentive when listening to him and don’t just lap up his words like a bunch of fatherless children desperately looking for guidance regardless of the source. Because trust me, that is his bread and butter - playing the Pied Piper leading lemurs off a cliff.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: The biggest issue I take with the whole anti-pornography thing, is the fact that people like Jordan are assuming that we only use it because it's easy. It is correct, delayed gratification is something that this society is starting to lose hold of and that is very important. However I think there's a caveat. As much as I like a lot of what Jordan says, I feel like he is operating on how things were back when he was dating and the fact that he's been married for so long almost puts blinders on him to wear he may expect men nowadays to act the way he did. He speaks out against corruption and also the degradation of the dating world so I feel like he should know these things and yet he seems to expect me to hold to the same standard that he did back in the day when things were so much better. I'm 35 and the difference between dating just from when I was in my twenties to now is astronomical. I could actually get dates 10 years ago. You think you get more experienced over time and your options get better but for me it's the opposite, I had more ability to do casual flings if I had wanted to and other things of that sort back when I was younger and more naive. Now my options are basically zero. Mainly because of what's happened to the dating world thanks to liberal ideals and feminism. So the question I put to him is, how am I supposed to do everything this correct way that you are speaking of, when I literally can't even get a single female of any repute to even look at me because all of them actively hate me. That's a little hyperbolic but I think the point still stands. I can't get any dating prospects in most circles because they've been corrupted. Where I live isn't very good either and I don't have the money to locate to a place that's a bit more conservative and actually has women that have been completely brainwashed. So basically I'm trapped. Any effort I've made over the last 5 years or so has met with either a direct disaster or completely self nullifies. So yeah, sometimes I consume a little bit of p*** just so I can feel something, so that I have some form of release instead of letting it all ball up on the inside and start poisoning me because regular release is healthy for you and considering the level of stress and depression I suffer from, I need something, anything. trust me, I would love to do it the right way and have a marriage and all that other good stuff but I literally can't find anyone who would consider me or is even a good match and has morals similar to my own. So where exactly does that leave me?

comment_text:
Jordon Peterson has shifted from being a thought-provoking professor to a full-blown ideological performer. Instead of challenging people to think critically, he now fuels division under the guise of rational debate. His early work was about personal responsibility and self-improvement—now it’s about playing culture war referee, feeding the outrage cycle, and reinforcing the echo chamber that keeps him relevant.

He knows exactly what he’s doing. His audience isn’t looking for nuance; they want confirmation that their worldview is correct and that they’re victims of some grand societal shift. And Peterson delivers, carefully picking battles that rile people up while avoiding any real critique of the power structures that actually dictate their lives.

comment_text:
18:36

JBP, I hope you realize that the attacks you faced at UToronto were largely because of your growing success and influence. When someone rises beyond expectations—beyond the institutions that once shaped them—it often triggers resistance. You didn’t just outgrow your role; you became bigger than the university itself.

I’m truly glad you made it through despite everything—the highs, the lows, and the immense pressure. Many wouldn’t have survived what you endured, and we all saw how close you came to losing your life due to benzo withdrawal. But through it all, God was with you. I only wish you emphasized more how your faith carried you through, how it played a crucial role in your survival.

You could have lost everything—your career, your life, your marriage, your family, your public standing. Yet, against all odds, you not only survived but emerged stronger and more successful than ever. That alone is a testament to resilience, faith, and purpose.
author: @MindShiftChronicle

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
About JBP saying he wished he met his wife earlier instead of later( when in fact they met at 8 separated and came back together 15 years later) ; It's obvious, I commented before finishing the video, but now that I’ve watched it, His -- Extreme  stance: I wish we were together since 8; since we met instead of 20 -- make more sense now in hindsight. Given how traditional and religious he presents himself, it aligns with his values. While this ideal is more pronounced in Islam than in Christianity, many believers—especially those with old-school values—see marrying their first love as a dream scenario.

That said, it’s becoming less and less common today, unless someone is deeply religious. I actually thought he was lucky to have been able to marry in his late twenties someone he met at eight years old. It’s honestly beautiful. It’s something I’ve always wanted too but never pursued—I wasn’t ready, and frankly, I couldn’t afford it when I was younger. Marrying young often requires strong parental support, which he clearly had.

After watching the video, I get the sense that when he briefly separated from Tammy during high school and university, he struggled with separation anxiety. He likely made some mistakes during that period (we don’t know exactly what), but eventually, they found their way back to each other in their twenties.

It’s possible that he viewed that decade apart as a time when neither of them was fully committed. Could it be that Tammy was with someone else during high school and university—maybe even lost her virginity to another guy before him? Women tend to mature faster, and since he described himself as a smaller, awkward kid in school, it wouldn’t be surprising if she had been with a more confident, older teenager. If that’s the case, it might have been devastating for him—especially since she was his childhood crush and next-door neighbor.

Most men have that one first love they wish they could have been with from the start, but immaturity and life circumstances often get in the way. It may sound silly, but given his stance against casual sex and his past struggles with heavy drinking, it wouldn’t be surprising if losing Tammy to someone else during that time played a role in his downward spiral. Many men—whether they admit it or not—want to be the first. Even if he acts like he’s above it, it’s a very real feeling.

In the end, very few people get to be with their first or even second big love—it takes a mix of luck, stability, and the right circumstances. In that sense, JBP is incredibly fortunate. Despite all his struggles, near-fatal health issues (benzo withdrawal), and depression, he still managed to build a stable family. That alone makes him an interesting model of resilience. Sorry for my long rambling hehe and my attempt to psychoanalysd him... 

So in other words he didn't wish he had had more time with her as he's saying but he wished he was with her in her most formative years-- teens and early adulthood; you know that important and disturbed phase of life( teens to young adulthood) and not later... IMO
author: @MindShiftChronicle

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: 16:25 I LOVE Jordan's answer to this question "If you were a fictional character who would you be?". Bugs Bunny. As a student of film, bugs bunny and the other Looney Tunes characters is a master class in characterization. Bugs Bunny is a good person through and through, he wasn't greedy like Daffy, he wasn't loud mouthed like Fog Horn Leg Horn, he didn't want to harm anyone else like Silvester the cat, he also wasn't a pet, like Tweety Bird, I can go on but Bugs was the ultimate good guy. If he was wronged, the famous line was, "I hope you realized this means war". Being as intelligent as he was he would find a clever way of beating the characters that wanted to do him harm. Just like Jordan himself. Bugs Bunny, being the mascot for Warner Brothers never fell into the roll of friendly, inoffensive mascot like Mickey Mouse. Bugs says what he thinks, stands up for himself, and is someone you want to be...no one wants to be Mickey Mouse.

comment_text:
I commented earlier about leaving my relationship and then returning. In the interim, I attempted to take my life by taking 196 pills at 9:00pm along with a large bottle of rum. I was on my bed my cell phone beside me. My son at his dad’s house. The next day my cell rang. He was calling me. I was on the floor. Somehow, I heard it and managed to answer and say help. They found me on the floor. My heart stopped multiple times on the way to the hospital. Keep in mind this was over 12 hours later. They gave me my last rites. I was in coma for some time. After I came home, I felt so horrible for attempting suicide. I was on my knees praying to God . Telling him how sorrowful I was. It was at that moment he spoke to me and said “Do not despair my child.”   

Regarding having a child, from a mothers point of view, the day you choose to have a child is the same as baring your soul or holding your heart in your hand unprotected for the rest of your life. Everything that affects your child good or bad effects you. You want nothing more than to see them succeed and be happy. You give birth and go through such pain. Every moment is worth it. And you raise them to be a part of your family and make your family complete knowing that once you’ve raised them they will go out into the world on their own and won’t be with you every day anymore. And you hope you did your best job raising them. And that they make the right decisions. It’s all bittersweet.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Jordan is so correct about a marriage ending when you don’t fight. For years I thought we had a great relationship because we never fought. After our son was born I was working full time and taking care of all household chores, shopping, 1 on 1 time with our son everything it took to run the house. Picking up his clothes off of the floor. I had brought my grievances to his attention multiple times. Nicely at first. Each time getting more upset. Writing it in a letter as some people learn differently. He continued to sit on the sofa and play Xbox and not have a part in our son’s life. While I became more upset each day that I was putting up with it and missing a great deal of our child’s wonder years. He would never say a word to me about it. He would never answer questions when I would ask him why he wouldn’t help. Or did he want us to leave. Finally I broke. Our son was 11. I was sick and still getting no help, no husband so I told him we were leaving . I said if he wanted us in his life he needed to step up and have 1 date night a week and one dinner night at our place a week and one dinner night at his place a week and every other week we would each take our son. He was not to play Xbox during that time. He moved us. And that was it. There is a big long story after that but he never ever fought. We are back together now. And he did a lot of dirty things. But he started speaking up and fighting. We are working things out. Our son is now 21. We’ve been married since 1999. Separated less than a year. I found out right after we were married when I went to visit him at his office after work that he was already cheating on me. I called him out.  We lived together for 4 years before we were married. I was his first girlfriend. He was my second husband. Our age is 3 years apart. When we got back together we took separate levels of the house. And we are slowly mending fences…..

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
He is so anxious. You can sense a person full of knowledge, eager to share it, but no one seems to want to listen. So, he talks fast, trying to pack as much information as possible into the brief moments he gets to reply. He desperately wants to be understood because he is often misunderstood.

It’s painful to listen to him; his anxiety seeps into you, and you need breaks just to cope with it. But beneath all of that, he makes sense. He’s a man of value, someone who talks about loyalty—a figure who seems like he’d be a good husband and father. Yet, if you’re young, you wouldn’t want to be like him; you’d find him intimidating or unsettling.

And then there’s the Huberman interview: calm, confident, and aspirational. He’s the kind of person you want to emulate. Yet, beneath the polished exterior, he lacks the same moral strength or the qualities of a good husband or a deeply loyal human being.

It’s a sad

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Peterson is pretty good at defining how transactional relationships are when it comes to pushing people into becoming attractive, but once he thinks about marriage, his mind goes blank and he becomes utterly incompetent.

His conclusion that living together before the marriage is the cause of its future failure just goes off to show how idiotically biased he is about this topic. His input is useless. If a test drive fails, any further attempt is doomed to fail too. When he started spewing this bullshit I tuned out, it's hard to take him seriously when he is so willing to be this incongruent.

Relationships never stop being transactional. A stupid vow in front of whatever witnesses won't stop that from being so and people have always traded up if that's an option. Stop fooling yourselves.

He seems to think there was a point in history where this idyllic version of pair-bonding happened continuously. The degree to which he imposes responsibility over an endeavor that relies on pure dumb luck, is exactly how he imposes guilt onto those unfortunates that experience relationship failure.

His contribution to this conversation is expired. Orion Taraban has far more realistic and current insight on these things.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
1:44:30 Bullshit. 
 
I have successfully created my own values, ive worked extremely hard at it and it comes at the price of never lying to yourself. It is possible, and its not just possible its entirely possible for everyone with an ever moderate IQ to do it. I have ever created my own philosophy which I am still constantly working on. 
 
This idea you can't create your own values and adhere to them is a dangerous, downright demonic idea.
 
This is a showcasing of Jordan Peterson's abundant weakness, and a great parallel of why he falls short of being a great person because of his (justified) hatred and anger towards those that have abused and humiliated him with vile lies and deception. He NEEDS god because he is not strong enough to come up with his own values on the spot and determine right from wrong. He relies on others to understand himself, and its a weakness.
 
Strive to be the Ubermench, knowing that the pinnacle is an impossible goal but aiming to be something like Jesus anyways.
 
If I had to sum up my whole moral and spiritual philosophy, it would be "The net reduction of suffering". Its not a all encompassing definition and there are caveats, but its a good philosophy, the best I have ever heard and I have learned all the philosophies I can. One of those caveats is to always look for opportunities to do something good that is easier for you to do than someone else, but don't punish yourself for not taking opportunity. I pick up trash on the ground when I am outside only if its on the path that I am already traveling because its easier for me to do that than someone to have the dedicated task to set aside against their other paths. If everyone did this, if everyone had this philosophy, we would have a lasting utopia that adapted to the changes of the world even with different moral frameworks of right and wrong, so long as we are honest with ourselves. 
 
Saying it is impossible to have your own belief and moral systems, is demonic.
 
There is nothing more valuable about Nietzsche's ideas than this one. Strive to be the Ubermench. Be the super man. Try to be Jesus, knowing perfection is unobtainable at an individual level. But it is not at scale.

comment_text: Jordan Peterson makes the mistake of denying the personality of God. He says that God is “The Spirit of Adventure” , the higher aim and what-not. God is personal. He wants to be known by us. Jesus Christ was a real person and God himself. He says that we can have and NEED redemption. Jordan realizes the profound brokenness of humanity but only tries to diagnose and treat the problem. Christ does that AND redeems us. Jordan only sees things through natural means and supposed evolution. Eternity is a long time to be wrong. God exists and we have an obligation to cooperate with his grace. You would never say that your wife is the “spirit of male companionship” or “the necessary mechanism of human reproduction”. That’s conceptualizing a real person. Don’t do that with God either. He is not a concept, he is a person.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: The chasm in the soul created by the harshness of humiliation can either be filled with a double dose of narcissism, self loathing, or, what I believe to be, the keystone of good: humility. I believe Jordan Peterson does his best to invite humility into this chasm. The idea of doing something “right,” especially in the context of good, can be subjective. However, when the attempt to do something "right" is joined with a sense of humility—coupled with the recognition that no one is perfect and must reach beyond themselves, beyond all human knowledge, and aim for the pinnacle of g(o)od—I believe leads us closer to something resembling objective truths of right and good.

comment_text: JP at his best. After years of watching him recover, it’s so good to see how fantastic and articulate he is. He’s not just a brilliant thinker but also a skilled communicator, which makes me constantly choose to guard myself. What he says rings so true (at least to himself) that I can’t help but admire him for speaking his truth. Authenticity in today’s modern world is so rare that, even when I disagree with his take or opinion—despite his authoritative and confident delivery—I still find myself respecting him. Especially in a time and space where I’m often ready to dismiss the self-absorbed, ego-driven, high-IQ thought leaders, JP stands out.

comment_text: To me a lot of this podcast is talking past the problem.  The problem is that men have been ridiculed into avoiding woman altogether.  I remember back in the day dudes would whistle at girls and were generally way more aggressive at hitting on woman.  But social norms have changed, and now a lot of men hesitate to approach women out of fear of making the girl feel uncomfortable.  Which would be a good thing except that we live in big cities where you don't see the same people every day like living in a small town.  There is no time to form organic relationships like you would in a small community.  So men are being conditioned to be more reserved and less aggressive at exactly the same time that sort of boldness is needed to break the ice in big city environments where you don't have the repeat interactions over time to organically form relationships.

comment_text:
What’s the point of marriage?

The reason things have gone sideways is that Boomers couldn’t or wouldn’t answer this question.

The point of marriage is to act as an external embodiment of conscience for the other members of the family; to call forth their most courageous, most authentic, most excellent self.

The ethos of marriage is: “I believe in your talent, and I can’t wait to see what you become. Who are you, and what do you want to do about it? How can I help you develop the skills you need to unleash your potential?” Who wouldn’t sign up for that deal?

Instead we turned the ethos of marriage into “I win.” Who wants to compete with their spouse?

comment_text: Wow!  Such an interesting discussion. As you mentioned in the interview Steven, you are starting to struggle with big questions and it is great to hear these sorts of discussions. Please can you also consider talking to very wise people from other religions as there is considerable commonality between the essence of the teachings of a number of religions (ancient and modern) - even if tragically, the human interpretation has lead to great divides - and I get that it would be a brave path to follow this (maybe do it privately if not on a podcast!). There is an underlying universal  truth in a number of re ligions - and although it resonates with so many people through their religion (and that is beautiful), you don’t have to follow a set religion to be asking these questions - if a particular religious core teachings don’t resonate fully, then there are other paths -  follow your own path of compassionate self enquiry. Your partner is a yoga teacher, so I guess she will understand - through the ancient teachings of yoga, that there is a personal path which does not take away from any religion. I am looking forward to you listening as you follow  your own path 🙏

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Your spouse is an external embodiment of your conscience. You need to spend 90 minutes a week communicating with that external source of conscience, and they need to spend 90 minutes a week with theirs.

It’s not about “why they don’t like you.” It’s about the ways you’re falling short of your potential, and making a plan to bridge the gap one step at a time. 

The ethos of marriage is “I believe in your talent, and I can’t wait to see what you become. Who are you, and what do you want to do about it? How can I help you develop the skills you need to unleash your potential?”

At least that was the ethos of marriage. Now it’s “I win,” and that’s why people stopped getting married.

comment_text:
Some of the take aways from this pod cast

1. Don't hold up, speak up and keep 90 mins every week to take feedback about what's not working and address it. If it accumulates it could be like 1500 hard talks you didn't have.
2. Don't ask who is the right partner for me, make yourself the best version of you be attractive to attract the best partner. 
3. Time is limited and you only get like 3-5 possible women or partner whom you will come across to know enough to be your life partner. Embrace the few you came across.
4. Issues needs to be drilled down to. The depth of the spiral and it could be coming from childhood or parents etc. 
5. When you look to resolve conflicts-it's also important to focus on what we want in the relationship. What both want is the key, sometimes we just have to replay the best memories from initial phases of love to recreate that spark again

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
13:37 - 13:52—This is very interesting because it seems that people nowadays are utilizing this "need to move on" much more for consumption than for life itself.

Instead of focusing on a new goal, learning new skills, meeting new people, and moving forward in life,

They instead focus on consuming products and content, such as buying a new jacket, the newest iPhone, a new couch or chair, or subscribing to a new YouTuber or content creator.

It really reminds me of this idea from "Fight Club" that we are just by-products of a lifestyle obsession. We have transformed from human beings into consumers.

The idea of moving onto something new is a NEED we have, and it's actually a good thing. It's this need that makes us stronger, smarter, harder working, innovating, and developing. It's what makes life interesting and meaningful.

But to apply this need to pure consumption instead of life is just a recipe for disaster.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: There were so many great nuggets in this conversation (using your voice, remembering your love in marriage, moving forward when discouraged by addictions, even the whole thing about being designed for challenge). However I found the spiritual discussion (and definitions) lacking, murky, diplomatic. I appreciated your sincere questions, your vulnerability and honesty about wrestling with the concept of God and religion. I hope you can have someone on who can dive deeper with clarity. Perhaps people who truly represent the best versions of various views? For what it's worth, I'm praying for you. I literally had to stop the video and just pray for you because I so resonated with what you shared and really hope you get your answers. We are all on journey. Your guest is no different but I would guess he isn't as far as long as one would think. He seems to have a reductionist, equalizing take that makes things easier to digest because "it's all the same" or it's pure evil. He speaks in a way in which most of us would nod our head, perhaps some of us with our head titled, eyes squinted, wondering if we really agree--but it's too late, the conversation moved on before we could question his reasoning further. Don't get me wrong. I got a lot out of it that I need to sit with and ponder. And it's quite possible he's so smart some of his points went over my head. But I don't think I'm off when I poke at the spiritual part. Even you had to ask a few times about his belief in God and who He is. And it was never clear. The voice of adventure (not a biblical or literal definition by the way, a perspective at best)? The highest, unattainable good? Meaning?  The best parts of us, accessible whether we're religious or not? 🤷🏾‍♀️ I didn't come away wanting to read his book. But I am curious what you found most helpful in it. Perhaps it's  the freedom to sit in this murky space of wrestling. I love that he noted Israel means wrestling with God. That's true.
author: @comfycozyknitting

comment_text: The way when he was asked if he believed Christ was God... came off as genuine to me despite the lack of reverence. I have found that most lay Christians do not really ponder the infinite depths of meaning beyond the surface. As an ocean is an ocean on top, as at the bottom,; so is truth. I find it hard to call myself a Christian because I do not feel I could EVER embody it. I constantly find myself pondering the meaning of life, love and God. It keeps coming back to HIM and HIS words, and it scares me and makes me feel shame and weak. Life seems to always circle around to Love is Sacrifice, both psychologically, metaphorically and divinely. As I ponder purpose, truth and the greatest good, sacrifice always comes back up and Christ is supposed to REPRESENT Sacrifice. You could spend your LIFE pondering the meaning of that. It is something more than just metaphor. It is Divine. It is something beyond literal, physical, and metaphorical. We are always so focused on Material Truth, but even that reflects Sacrifice. Everything in existence is the result of something prior to it.... you can say it was "sacrificed" for the existence of the next thing. Happy people generally have other people that they "Sacrifice" their time and energy to support and help. There are a infinite examples both literal, metaphorical, and material that reflect Sacrifice. Christ EMBODIES it. I still cannot completely wrap my head around the depth of what that means.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Jordan Peterson has faced significant controversy, with accusations of promoting fascist ideologies and conspiracy theories, as well as challenges regarding his professional license.

Fascist Claims and Conspiracy Theories:

- Cultural Marxism: Peterson has been linked to the concept of cultural Marxism, which is often associated with far-right ideologies. A critical analysis states, "Peterson’s rabid anti-leftism makes him an easy mark for fascist propaganda" and highlights how he has helped bring this conspiracy theory into the mainstream, suggesting that it is rooted in anti-Semitic tropes. Source: Pacific Standard

- Indoctrination Conspiracy: Peterson has claimed, "There’s a grand conspiracy to indoctrinate good, righteous Canadians in their cribs," which critics argue aligns with fascist propaganda targeting leftists. This rhetoric is seen as dangerous and reminiscent of historical fascist narratives. Source: Pacific Standard

- Dangerous Rhetoric: Peterson has stated that the outcomes of leftist ideologies are "much the same" as those of Leninist insurrection, which critics label as dangerous nonsense that can justify extreme violence. Source: Pacific Standard

Professional License and Regulatory Challenges:

- Social Media Training Requirement: Peterson has been ordered to undergo social media training or risk losing his license to practice. He described this requirement as a form of re-education, stating, "The right of the College to do so has now been upheld by a provincial court, despite their apparent admission that it could infringe on my fundamental rights." Source: CBC News

- Public Commentary on Regulatory Actions: Peterson expressed his defiance, saying, "I’m perfectly willing to air my dirty laundry in public," as he battles the College of Psychologists of Ontario over their demands. Source: Toronto Sun

- Criticism of the College's Actions: He criticized the College, claiming they are going too far and that their actions violate his Charter right to freedom of expression. He stated, "I want the entire current crop of minions at the College of Psychologists to publicly apologize and then resign en masse." Source: National Post.
author: @BenjaminCarminner

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
When Peterson talks about truth, good, and God, he seems to point to something fundamental: the nature of reality itself. His argument could be summarized like this:

There will always be losses and sacrifices in life - that's inevitable. But we have a choice: we can either passively accept whatever losses come our way, or actively choose what to sacrifice through voluntary commitment. The latter gives us some agency and helps build something meaningful.

When someone asks "Why should I take on any responsibility or sacrifice anything at all?", Peterson's answer is essentially: because that's the nature of reality. It's like asking "Why must I eat?" or "Why must I sleep?" The answer is simple: because that's how reality and your organism work. You can try to ignore it, but you'll end up hungry and tired.

Similarly, you can't just "decide" that gravity doesn't affect you, and you can't "decide" to live without any sacrifice or responsibility. Of course, you can try to live avoiding all sacrifice and responsibility - but there will be consequences, and you won't like them. That's the thing about reality - you can ignore its rules, but you cannot escape the consequences of ignoring them.

Sure, you could try to live purely for pleasure, avoiding all sacrifice and responsibility. But Peterson argues this paradoxically leads to more suffering - like a house built without foundations, it won't withstand life's storms. It's not sustainable and won't provide real fulfillment or shelter when things get tough.

It's like he's saying: "You can't have everything" - and trying to avoid all sacrifice is precisely trying to have everything, which by definition must fail because it goes against the fundamental nature of reality and human existence.
author: @Krzy-hoo

comment_text:
(I’m not trying to convince anyone of anything here. Just sharing.) 
I’m so glad this channel had already established a lot of trust with me. If this had been my first exposure to DOAC, I never would have returned. I really admire Steven’s interviewing  and sharing here, and I can appreciate how important it is to bring many different perspectives in to the show’s larger discourse. I watched this twice in an attempt to stay open-minded. But Peterson’s sheer lack of intellectual rigor is baffling for someone with his background. The massive logical leaps masquerading as age-old wisdom, the narrow filtering of facts massaged into the shape of his preferred narrative…I can see why his work is a popular stop on the incel pipeline.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: The Bible can't be a study of evolutionary motivations because the Bible has no knowledge of evolution. From a biblical perspective, there is an omniscient God who created every animal to belong to its own environmental niche, and no adaptation over time was needed because everything fit together in natural harmony due to its having been designed by an all-knowing intelligence. In fact, it is *impossible* to reconcile the creation story of Genesis 1-3 with evolution because evolution presupposes that God created the natural world we experience as-is, and humanity developed via cycles of suffering and death within that natural world, whereas the Genesis account presents God as having created humanity whole-cloth in a protected environment such that suffering and death were impossible for humanity to experience until they merited it through misbehavior. This is because the purpose of the Genesis account is to justify God's goodness, and a good God would not have created a world in which suffering and death plagued humanity from the beginning. In the Jewish mind, bad things can only happen to people who deserve it in some way, shape, or form, so God could not allow humanity to experience suffering and death until humanity misbehaved in some way.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
I appreciate the self-improvement message he promotes—taking control of your life is a positive and empowering idea. However, I often feel like he places a lot of emphasis on men fixing their own problems while largely avoiding addressing how women, and their methods of selecting partners, might also not only contribute to the challenges men face and might not work with the free and technologically advance society we live in. It’s like he treats women’s selection methods as something that can’t or shouldn’t be changed or addressed.

I understand his audience is primarily men, so that’s who he focuses on. I also know his books are meant to be for everyone and aren’t necessarily gender-specific. But I can’t help thinking back to something he said on Joe Rogan’s podcast years ago: “If you’re a young man and all the women are rejecting you, who has the problem? It’s not all the women.” That statement sticks with me and turns me off from his message because its deaf to the actual problem between the sexes especially whenever he talks almost exclusively about men needing to change.

While his advice to “be a man and you might make it” is valid, it feels incomplete because it doesn’t touch on the role women play or the potentially problematic aspects of how mate selection works in today’s technologically advanced society. I believe he doesn't talk about it because extreme views and actions would be discussed.  Maybe I’m selectively hearing what I want to hear when he speaks, but he doesn't talk about women's role or duty in society.
author: @ShatsBassoon
