video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Where Did We Come From?
1:40:23 
WHY DOES THE ANSWER MATTER? Many people are taught that life on earth emerged by accident. They are told that through a series of unlikely, random events, evolution produced the human race with all its emotional, intellectual, and spiritual capacities.

But consider: If we really are the product of evolution and there is no Creator, the human race would, in a sense, be an orphan. Mankind would have no source of superior wisdom to consult​—no one to help us solve our problems. We would have to rely on human wisdom to avert environmental disaster, to solve political conflicts, and to guide us through our personal crises.

Do these prospects bring you peace of mind? If not, contemplate the alternative. Not only is it more appealing but it also makes more sense.

What the Bible Says

The Bible teaches that mankind is a direct creation of God. We are not the product of uncaring, mindless evolution. Rather, we are the children of a loving, intelligent Father. Note these clear statements made in the Bible.

Genesis 1:27. “God proceeded to create the man in his image, in God’s image he created him; male and female he created them.”

Psalm 139:14. “I shall laud you because in a fear-inspiring way I am wonderfully made. Your works are wonderful, as my soul is very well aware.”

Matthew 19:4-6. “Did you not read that he who created them from the beginning made them male and female and said, ‘For this reason a man will leave his father and his mother and will stick to his wife, and the two will be one flesh’? So that they are no longer two, but  one flesh. Therefore, what God has yoked together let no man put apart.”

Acts 17:24, 25. “The God that made the world and all the things in it, being, as this One is, Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in handmade temples, neither is he attended to by human hands as if he needed anything, because he himself gives to all persons life and breath and all things.”

Revelation 4:11. “You are worthy, Jehovah, even our God, to receive the glory and the honor and the power, because you created all things, and because of your will they existed and were created.”

How the Bible’s Answer Brings Real Peace of Mind

Knowing that “every family . . . on earth owes its name” to God alters the way we view other people. (Ephesians 3:15) Having such knowledge also influences how we view ourselves and our problems. Our thinking will be affected in the following ways.

When faced with difficult decisions, we will not become unduly worried about man’s conflicting opinions. Instead, we will confidently rely on the Bible’s counsel. Why? Because “all Scripture is inspired of God and beneficial for teaching, for reproving, for setting things straight, for disciplining in righteousness, that the man of God may be fully competent, completely equipped for every good work.”​—2 Timothy 3:16, 17.

True, applying the Bible’s counsel involves effort and self-discipline. Sometimes its guidance may even require that we act in ways that seem contrary to our inclinations. (Genesis 8:21) However, if we accept that we were created by a loving heavenly Father, it is only logical to conclude that he knows the best course for us to take. (Isaiah 55:9) His Word thus assures us: “Trust in Jehovah with all your heart and do not lean upon your own understanding. In all your ways take notice of him, and he himself will make your paths straight.” (Proverbs 3:5, 6) If we apply that counsel, much of the anxiety we experience when facing challenges and decisions will be removed.

When confronted by prejudice, we will not be burdened by feelings of inferiority, thinking that we are somehow less valuable than people of a different race or another cultural background. Instead, we will develop a healthy sense of self-respect. Why? Because our Father, Jehovah God, “is not partial, but in every nation the man that fears him and works righteousness is acceptable to him.”​—Acts 10:34, 35.

This realization will also prevent us from allowing prejudice to warp our attitude toward others. We will appreciate that there is no legitimate basis for feeling superior to people of another race, since God “made out of one man every nation of men, to dwell upon the entire surface of the earth.”​—Acts 17:26.

Certainly, knowing that we were created and that our Creator cares for us lays the foundation for gaining real peace of mind. But more is needed if we are to maintain inner peace.
author: @dezlauman2153

comment_text:
1:38:58 Why You Can Trust the Bible?

Some people say the Bible is unreliable, and their views have gained wide acceptance. Thus many today dismiss what the Bible says as untrustworthy.

On the other hand, what Jesus Christ said in prayer to God promotes trust: “Your word is truth.” And the Bible itself claims to be inspired by God.—John 17:17; 2 Timothy 3:16.

What do you think about this? Is there sound basis for trusting the Bible? Or is there really evidence that the Bible is unreliable, that it contradicts itself and is inconsistent?

Does It Contradict Itself?

While some may claim the Bible contradicts itself, has anyone ever shown you an actual example? We have never seen one that could withstand scrutiny. True, there may appear to be discrepancies in certain Bible accounts. But the problem usually is lack of knowledge regarding details and circumstances of the times.

For example, some persons will draw attention to what they consider a discrepancy in the Bible, asking: ‘Where did Cain get his wife?’ The assumption is that Cain and Abel were the only children of Adam and Eve. But the assumption is based on a misunderstanding of what the Bible says. The Bible explains that Adam “became father to sons and daughters.” (Genesis 5:4) Thus Cain married one of his sisters or possibly a niece.

 Often critics are just looking for contradictions and so may declare: ‘The Bible writer Matthew says that an army officer came to ask Jesus a favor, while Luke says that representatives were sent to ask. Which one is correct?’ (Matthew 8:5, 6; Luke 7:2, 3) But is this really a contradiction?

When the activity or work of people is credited to the one who is actually responsible for it, a reasonable person does not claim a discrepancy. For example, do you consider a report to be in error that says a mayor built a road even though the actual building of the road was done by his engineers and laborers? Of course not! Similarly, it is not inconsistent for Matthew to say that the army officer made a request of Jesus but, as Luke writes, that such a request was made through certain representatives.

As more details are known, apparent discrepancies in the Bible disappear.

History and Science

The historical accuracy of the Bible was once widely doubted. Critics, for example, questioned the existence of such Bible characters as King Sargon of Assyria, Belshazzar of Babylon, and the Roman governor Pontius Pilate. But recent discoveries have verified one Bible account after another. Thus historian Moshe Pearlman wrote: “Suddenly, sceptics who had doubted the authenticity even of the historical parts of the Old Testament began to revise their views.”

If we are to trust the Bible, it must also be accurate in matters of science. Is it? Not long ago scientists, in contradiction of the Bible, asserted that the universe had no beginning. However, astronomer Robert Jastrow recently pointed to newer information that  refutes this, explaining: “Now we see how the astronomical evidence leads to a biblical view of the origin of the world. The details differ, but the essential elements in the astronomical and biblical accounts of Genesis are the same.”—Genesis 1:1.

Men have also changed their views relative to the shape of the earth. “Voyages of discovery,” explains The World Book Encyclopedia, “showed that the world was round, not flat as most people had believed.” But the Bible was correct all along! More than 2,000 years before those voyages, the Bible said at Isaiah 40:22: “There is One who is dwelling above the circle of the earth,” or as other translations say, “the globe of the earth” (Douay), “the round earth.” (Moffatt)

Thus the more humans learn, the greater the evidence is that the Bible can be trusted. A former director of the British Museum, Sir Frederic Kenyon, wrote: “The results already achieved confirm what faith would suggest, that the Bible can do nothing but gain from an increase of knowledge.”

Foretelling the Future

But can we really trust the Bible’s forecasts for the future, including its promises of a ‘righteous new  heavens and new earth’? (2 Peter 3:13; Revelation 21:3, 4) Well, what has been the Bible’s record of reliability in the past? Time and time again prophecies given even hundreds of years in advance have been fulfilled in exact detail!

For example, the Bible foretold the overthrow of mighty Babylon nearly 200 years before it happened. In fact, the Medes, who became aligned with the Persians, were named as the conquerors. And although Cyrus, the Persian king, had not even been born as yet, the Bible foretold that he would be prominent in the conquest. It said that Babylon’s protecting waters, the river Euphrates, “must be dried up,” and that “the gates [of Babylon] will not be shut.”—Jeremiah 50:38; Isaiah 13:17-19; 44:27–45:1.

These specific details were fulfilled, as the historian Herodotus reported. Further, the Bible foretold that Babylon would eventually become uninhabited ruins. And that is just what happened. Today Babylon is a desolate heap of mounds. (Isaiah 13:20-22; Jeremiah 51:37, 41-43) And the Bible is full of other prophecies that have had dramatic fulfillment.

What then does the Bible foretell concerning the present world’s system of things? It says: “The final age of this world is to be a time of troubles. Men will love nothing but money and self; they will be arrogant, boastful, and abusive; with no respect for parents, no gratitude, no piety, no natural affection . . . They will be men who put pleasure in the place of God, men who preserve the outward form of religion, but are a standing denial of its reality.”—2 Timothy 3:1-5, The New English Bible.

Surely, we are seeing the fulfillment of this now!  But the Bible also foretells for “the final age of this world” these things: “Nation will rise against nation and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be food shortages.” In addition, “there will be great earthquakes, and in one place after another pestilences.”—Matthew 24:7; Luke 21:11.

Indeed, Bible prophecies are undergoing fulfillment today! Well, then, what about yet-to-be-fulfilled promises, such as: “The righteous themselves will possess the earth, and they will reside forever upon it,” and, “They will have to beat their swords into plowshares . . . , neither will they learn war anymore”?—Psalm 37:29; Isaiah 2:4.

‘That’s just too good to be true,’ some may say. But really, there is no reason for us to doubt anything that our Creator promises. His Word can be trusted! (Titus 1:2) By examining the evidence further, you will become ever more convinced of this.

Jehovah's Witnesses use the Bible.
As the reliable source rather than tradition or populism.
To inform themselves.
Viewing the Bible as our Fathers reliable letter to us.
Outline how Jehovah/Yahweh Almighty God wants us to reunite into his family.

To answer your question, “Does my dog have a different God than me?” A: No. Read Genesis 1 & 2.

I admire both Jordan, and you Stephen. I really do. I appreciated Jordan’s stunning brilliance and insights. I appreciate the insightful questioning that you bring to the table, drawing out of your guests what many podcasters miss. That’s a gift… from God. So, when it comes to the question about the existence of God, being wrestled with here, according to my own experience, it is a personal relationship with God that is lacking in the conversation. That once you’ve experience, it becomes an undeniable truth.

God, as He did with Abraham, Moses, and other notable figures we read about in the Bible, spoke into my life when I was a young adult. That is to say, not only did He answer my sincere prayer, “God if you’re real let me know.” which He did in a very personal, even miraculous way, but He also spoke to my mind giving me answers to questions I had that were completely outside of my realm of understanding. They were a revelation to me. In this way God - to be clear, the God of the Judeo-Christian Bible - continues to reveal Himself to me today through that Bible.

Thank you again!

comment_text: Jordan (while I am a general fan) has a problem. He can’t maintain the concept of evolution AND God (in the Christian sense) at the same time. I felt that Steven genuinely wanted truth - or at least Jordan’s version of truth but did not get it as JP is on the fence. If you believe in God ie the man in the sky, then you believe he created everything - therefore our ‘instincts’ and what is good were also hardwired into us, by him. Now, of course, we evolve but with a small ‘e’. If you believe that we Evolved from accidents of the universe this almost rules out God. This has a huge impact on how one thinks we came about and what we should do. If there is ‘God’ reality and morality is predetermined. If evolution - then these things are all up for interpretation. Long story short - you have to choose where to place faith - you can’t reconcile believing in both.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: The moment I realized my addiction to drugs stemmed from lying and promiscuity was the moment I turned into someone that wouldn'tneed to numb myself from myself. The cognitive dissonance had me so full of anxiety, I couldn't bear to the weight of the stress. I knew what I was doing was wrong at a very young age... I was raised in a Catholic church and school. Regardless of what I think about that religion now, at the time, I believed what I had been taught. I gave myself to God through many sacraments. The moment I tossed all of my "sacredness" to the side, every other bad act I did fell into that pile, too. That pile just consumed me. So- I agree with Jordan, and I'm grateful that teachers like him still exist in this world. I wish I had never given my sexuality up for attention. Its not sexual freedom or feminism. It was a prison. That's what I would change if I could go back in time. But still, today at 52, it feels AMAZING to live with enough Grace to forgive myself and still live without lying and disregarding my values. And it'll sure help keep you from not needing a drink or drug to escape from myself.  To thy own self be true actually did save my soul❤🎉

comment_text:
I agree with you. "Faulty" yes, but I do not comfortably have.. or find.. the clarity to single out what is faulty, what exactly is "well-said" and what was not exactly that much right. I said (above in this comments section) that some concepts and categories are all mixed-up here like a function of the dialogue. But this is intimidating simply because WE the AUDIENCE are exposed to a shapeless, almost virtual cloud of information and do not know what to do with this cloud. There are many "whys?" and "hows?" left unanswered with a backdrop of intellectual sophistication. 

True teachers let people see things with more clarity which doesn't have to come from a religious perspective. But even the religious perspective hasn't been given with clarity here, burdened with an extension to Greco-Roman traditions (who believed in Olympian Gods, basically, and ived through loyalty to, fear of, pleasures allowed by them as their lives followed patterns best exemplified in the stories about them).

In a nutshell, people ask Jordan Peterson to resolve a crisis of "Being The Western Civilization" and not even the most beautiful French girl can do for a man anything better than all what she can.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
@@Ha4r4eset I completely agree with “things used to progress much slower.”  Humans evolved in small tribes and towns where we mostly dealt with the same people everyday. Now we live in big cities where people are constantly coming and going. Even though we’re surrounded by more people than ever, few of us have time to build real rapport. It’s not just the internet—it’s the relentless pace of modern urban life.

In the past, men often approached directly and confidently, knowing there might not be a second chance. This was common in the ’80s, ’90s, and early 2000s (remember cat calling and whistling?). While not always welcome, it created a culture where direct approaches were expected—sometimes opening the door for meaningful connection.

Then, around 2017, workplace and social norms shifted rapidly. Campaigns around conduct gained traction, and many organizations adopted strict policies.  These basically succeeded at stamping out unwanted behavior by men in public.

But we’re still in fast-moving cities—and removed one of the few tools for forming quick connections. In environments where politeness and hesitation don’t lead anywhere, what fills the gap?

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Peterson made every effort to conceal his belief in God, aware that revealing it would prompt numerous questions, especially regarding his belief in a man-God, Jesus. Although he personally does not subscribe to the idea of a man-God, he feels compelled to articulate this belief due to the expectations tied to his paycheck. It's important to note that Jesus never claimed to be God; instead, he consistently acknowledged that God, who sent him to guide humanity, was greater than himself. Consider the notion of a God who couldn't save Himself—while Jesus imparts some valuable teachings, he often complicates issues and may harbor a hidden agenda. Kudos to Steve for challenging him with tough questions about his beliefs

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
This was a phenomenal interview.  I watched a recent interview with Jordan, and walked away wondering if he had faith.  In God.  Does he hang his life upon Him?  I ask that because he seems to approach things in analytical ways, or in how others might write about the human condition.  But does he have faith?  It would be a good area to explore, particularly during his difficult 3 years. What does he look forward to AFTER death?

He had very interesting comments about "the adventure", or a personal path of growth.  Has he considered that being created, that God might want him (Jordan) to "grow up" and be like Him? (he didn't buy into the darwinistic approach, though he entertained Steven's single cell/sperm example)  There were a couple of moments that I felt like Jordan wouldn't share some existential answers, and perhaps that's through wisdom in not "giving" them to Steven.  Or perhaps it's to sacred to share.  Or afraid of being wrong at such an individual conclusion that may affect others differently?.  Steven asked some VERY in-depth and vulnerable questions, but he's not willing to have faith as well.  He seems to search for WHY, but with explanations that he can accept.  And faith is a VERY vulnerable attribute to exercise, because there's no evidence for say... an "unseen" thing or God.    You have to be willing to lay it ALL down and put trust in Him.  

You might be pleasantly surprised at what you find.... or come to know.  And I know.  I CAN'T deny Him.  But it took a LOT of faith and devoted study to get that revelation.
author: @jum5238

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Abram already had a wife when he was called to adventure. 

JP has an ongoing problem ascribing personhood to God. Yes, God is the ultimate good, but above all, He is Being and is personal. He is the source of all reality.

Unfortunately, JP's dedication to evolutionary theory is a stumbling block to faith in God as the Creator. However, if he were to examine the biochemistry behind life, this might cease to be the case. Although Darwin could observe natural selection (the change in organisms through loss of genetic information), he never observed true evolution (the creation of new genetic information to create more complex organisms from simpler ones). Darwin was completely unaware of the existence of DNA when he came up with his theory. This theory has been assumed to be true and is used to explain the advantages of various organs, behaviours, etc without in any way being able to explain how any of them could come to be in a stepwise fashion. For example, an egg is incredibly finely tuned. If any one step in its production is defective, there is no next generation. 

I highly recommend Michael Behe's book, "Darwin's Black Box" and Marcos Eberlin's book, "Foresight"!

comment_text: This was so refreshing. I’m a progressive who is in a committed relationship with a conservative. We can find middle ground politically, and then agree to disagree on the hard stuff, but being in line with your partner is so beautiful, and we are definitely playing the same game together (and we both enjoy that game). video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Why So Serious??😠🤡 Mr Peterson obviously has a bunch of fast sparking neural pathways chock full of erudite material & latest churned buzz words from psychology theory but he labours glibly under the burden of perpetually viewing life through the lens of overly emphasised semiotics - never smiling - no joy apparent in the delivery. Yes humans need archetypal mythological stories to understand & make sense of the world they inhabit and comedy/trickster role is an important element of staying sane in a chaotic unpredictable environment that helps people  bond together through humour/laughing in the face of monstrous adversity. Comedy is the ultimate tool of disarmament.  Its unfortunate JP's joyless projection from taking himself way too seriously makes him look constipated throughout the entire interview, in need of a large glass of juice & an urgent high voltage enema to provide some light relief🤣 🍵🌋💩

comment_text: I wish they talked more about what porn does to a relationship - not just how it affects men (i.e sex being an "accomplishment"). What I think a lot of people don't realise, is that if you're getting sexual gratification from porn whilst in a committed relationship/marriage, it's essentially the same thing having mental sex with someone who isn't your partner. Back in the day before pornography, men simply went to brothels. I'm sure most women today would have a serious issue if their partners frequented brothels (other than the STD risk of course) because it's simply cheating and betrayal. But  many people have tricked themselves into believing that porn isn't the same thing. The screen of a laptop and anonyminity doesn't fundamentally change the action.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Jordan Peterson is incredibly wise but I vehemently disagree that there's anything wrong with being in a long-term committed relationship with someone and wanting to live with them and have sex with them before you're married. My wife and I lived and slept together for years before we married and we have an incredibly happy healthy marriage. We didn't have sex straight away (waited a few months) and waited several years to move in together, but I think committing to be with someone for the rest of your life without ever sleeping with them or living with someone is not best for everyone. He doesn't acknowledge that the statistics on divorce don't account for reverse causality, ie people who are less likely to get divorced are less likely to live together before marriage. This is a bastardization of the data in my view.

comment_text:
Dr Peterson is one of the main reasons at 38 years old I began a journey to gain a degree in psychology. I have just under 4 months left. One thing that I hold onto whenever I have had moments of self doubt. "you do not get the gold if you do not fight the dragon". For those who have tried to destroy his reputation, are the same people who destroy good people and stop them chasing their dreams. The establishment sickens me more after the 4 years of studying, than before I began. I never believed that was possible. The system is broken, when you can't voice the truth and inspire people to be a better version of themselves.

For what it is worth Dr Peterson I may massively disagree with your support for Tommy Robinson, but you have been the guiding light on many other subjects. It's OK to not always agree.

On a side note… 

I desperately wanted to take in what Jordan had to say in an uncomplicated way. He has many valid points that we could all benefit from.

I only happened to come across a photo of him with a Canadian politician by chance that supports Trump that’s making headlines atm.

Steven seems so far removed from the insanity of us vs them, right vs left, right vs wrong, immoral vs moral, so I believe his intentions were admirable….however…..
What I just saw was disappointing. I’m more than happy to call it confirmation bias, consider my view of Jordan’s beliefs …I want to believe that the human race wants to love and support each other, but a photo op with a clearly right leaning individual is disappointingly biased 😢

comment_text: @@nathaliesavoury7736 I've heard more than enough from Jordan Peterson and have no interest in spending another two hours listening to him stir controversy. Just one minute into this video, there’s already enough material to spark a heated debate between men and women. The real world, however, isn’t as black-and-white as his arguments often make it seem—it’s full of nuance, complexity, and shades of gray. Yet, many people prefer to avoid that gray area, opting instead for the comfort of rigid, oversimplified narratives. Perhaps that’s why his rhetoric remains so divisive, and I try to stay clear of such speakers.
author: @X2OCanada

comment_text: I have not yet completed the podcast, approximately half way. It is certainly a good podcast, good discussions. What I find interesting so far is that in all the discussions around marriage and relationships, Jordan Peterson talks about why women would avoid men, but not why men would avoid women. He does not talk about the divorce rates, the family courts, or the darker traits of female nature. He promotes marriage without addressing the enormous danger it poses for men in the modern day. I am not the first to say this, but some believe Jordan Peterson is scared of feminists and a bit of a mommy's boy. Once you start to see it you can't unsee it. Anyways, perhaps he will address it in the latter half of the podcast. Regardless, good stuff and great discussions

comment_text:
@@danielrubiop I understand your perspective. If I can, I’d like to explain why I think it’s really selfless even if it seems self-serving in the end. 

I’m coming from a perspective that (with the same example) gaining more wealth in order to provide yourself a family actually means more responsibility, more effort and ultimately a larger burden. You’re taking on more responsibility, more work and burden for own self service? We may think we do it for ourselves, for status or pleasure of consumption but ultimately once we have children, we realize it was all selfless and it was all for them. The eventual reproduction that usually happens when you become a successful adult. It’s so subconscious and instinctually ingrained that we think we are serving ourselves but we are actually serving the future children we will have. And that’s how it should be. The older always protecting the younger. Even when the older think they are doing for themselves or their status, it’s for the children that will come from that success. 

Individuals that gain wealth/success usually always have a family or try to/want to.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
The question  "How can I learn to offer something to someone else that would make me  eminently desirable". Fair enough, good advice for less than 50% of the single population, ie young and middle-aged men. 
However it doesn't apply to women nearly so much, because men are attracted to physical beauty, and let's face it, that's what you are born with or not. You can't really change it, unless the reason for your unattractiveness is that you are grossly overweight or have a physical deformity that can be easily fixed. If you are say in the bottom 30% of physical attractiveness as a woman, you can do all the things a man does to make himself attractive, and it won't work that well (on the average, of course there are exceptions). Become financially secure or even very wealthy and it will likely only attract fortune hunting men.  Work out at the gym? Nah, won't really work, unless you are just hanging out for a quick "hook-up" (which most women aren't). Plastic surgery....you pay a lot of money and end up looking weird.
In particular for older widowed women (and let's face it men die younger than women), it is unsuitable advice and would give such women false hope. An older female friend once said to me, if you are widowed (or divorced), once you are over a certain age as a woman, men of around your age will only want you for two things, "Nurse or purse"! Toy boys? A generally ridiculous suggestion, unless say, you just want an escort for a night out or just a sexual "hook-up".
And for the average older widowed men, this advice doesn't work so much either, unless you have a very big fortune (then women will "turn a blind eye" to your age). And you can work out at the gym as much as you want, it won't give you the body of a younger man. 
Some things (aging singleness through no fault of your own) you just have to accept, or you will bring great unhappiness upon yourself by living with false expectations.
Of course, none of this precludes you, at any age and regardless of whether you are male or female, from making yourself the kind of person people want to be friends with, and that family members love and want to be with.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: I would be interested to see him discuss the divorce within the context of no fault divorce decreasing the number of female suicides by around 20%. Does increased female availability in the long-term dating market truely benefit these women, and society as women make up a large portion of it? Does underachieving actually make women happier? Could some of the unhappiness reported by high achieving women be the same as high achieving men who also report unhappiness? Doesn't the shrinking social support circle and shared tasks of daily living which were once communal but are now solitary also share a role in current societal difficulties? Dr. Peterson seems to place a lot of emphasis on the nuclear family unit but was about the more traditional social structures of hunter gatherer societies? In one study I saw women in modern hunter gatherer societies have their menesis later (14, 15, or 16) and experience far more social supports in spite of their "smaller communities." I have been listening to Dr. Peterson on and off for a while now and I can't help but feel that these conversations could be expanded through more critical back and forth on some of these concepts.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: He has a lot to teach, he is very knowledgeable, very insightful, but I noticed a pattern with Peterson that triggered me, I tried to unsee it because his arguments are so interesting and often enlightening, however, he interrupted the host continuously. At one time even when he was told by the host that he wanted to finish the question, he insisted he needed to clarify why he interrupted, however he never allowed the question to be completely asked and he hijacked the conversation by totally navigating to a different topic, sort of turned it onto something that benefited his point of view. The host never got to ask that question.  Given the intriguing nature of the topic I was truly interested in hearing that one question, I think that Peterson has a lot of valuable tools that can help others but in a way he could improve his communication style by being more considerate about what others have to say. Even when we do know that the question may have little value or possibly not asked correctly, there is a lot of value ( respect) in letting the other person verbalize what they have to say, then address rather then interrupt to address.

comment_text: I first started listening to him through his academic lectures - which gave an interesting different perspective, but it was taken as being idiosyncratic (like his maps of meaning - those are the meanings he attributes - not necessarily what everyone would). His progression has become one where he states his perspective as if it was the absolute  truth ["Obviously!"], which not only kills contemplation of the veracity of his statement - but feels like it is stated to prevent any alternative perspective. In essence, I think it has become harder for some (myself included) to listen to him because of his increasing dogma and intolerance of other ways of being - and the inconsistencies in what he says and does. However, he is an interesting character - and Steve does a brilliant job interviewing him. I just don't put much stock in following his word as if it were gospel (or anywhere close to it) :)

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: When Peterson says that "play" helps us with staying with the same person forever, I'd add that we are NOT the same person forever: we evolve and we change and we mature and we molt and morph into older but wiser versions of ourselves. THIS is what brings novelty to a relationship: we are not going to live the same day over and over again with the person we met years ago. Life is unpredictable and we will face several transformative adventures together that will shape who we'll become. And if we succeed in passing through life's trials and growing from them, we should be able to fall in love with one another over and over again, at different stages of the relationship (that is, if both partners do grow). It's anything but boring! The tricky part is resisting the hormonal urge to seek novelty outside of the relationship, and I'm a woman so I don't know about men, but I know that hormones can be pretty powerfull in the effects they have on our feelings, libido, drives, etc. Sublimation in arts is an option that I like in those moments (because they are only moments, it's cyclical), because you're at your pic creativity in those moments of hormonal storm.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Wow, Steven!!
I've seen hundreds of interviews with Jordan and by now I almost always know instinctively how he's going to answer the questions and how he lays out his arguments.
Although there where nothing really novel about the topics in this interview I believe you managed to ask the right questions with the right timing all throughout the interview because he really had to give some fresh takes on stuff I've heard him regurgitate for years.
This was one of the best interviews with Jordan I've heard so far and one of the best one I've heard you conduct!
I think the reason that you do this better than 99% of all journalists is that you have done your research, you are an honest person and that you actually is curious and interested in the answers. The consequences are that you actually listens (instead of trying to get YOUR point across) and therefore you are able to ask questions with razor precision in both the context and temporal sense.
I been working inside of main stream media for two decades and seen all styles of journalism.
This is, by far, the best!
Brilliant, Mr Bartlett!!💪🏼❤️👍🏼

comment_text:
The word ‘tosser’ is a derogatory term that arose from coin tossing, specifically a gambling game many men played when they’d given up trying to queue for the mere chance of a job during The Depression. Different beginnings but similar disgust used for men that do something else instead of chasing and competing for the mere chance of the attention of women. Coincidence? I don’t think so. (It’s described as a sex ‘drive’ for a reason.)
I think we’re built for trying to attain enlightenment. We may not attain it, but to actively throw our chance away is repugnant to most.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Why You Should Wait - 10 Reasons 

1. The 'A Plan'. God's perfect plan is not for fatherless children to be roaming the earth but for all children to be born to parents who love and are committed to each other. Any child who has a parent that isn't playing an active role in their lives will know rejection. 

2. Blueprint. In Jewish culture, a covenant was formed by the planting of a seed/ tree or by people cutting their wrists and exchanging blood. God designed sex to be a COVENANT (aka promise). The act of sex is a promise of faithfulness. 

3. Soul ties. Sex impacts us on more than just a physical level. When soul ties are formed there is typically a fallout when the ties are broken/ one attempts to break them. 

4. Intimacy. Nobody should 'know' you better than your spouse. If you have been more sexually or emotionally intimate with somebody from your past than you are with your spouse, this can cause problems in your marriage. 

5. Wheat from the chaff. If somebody really loves you and not simply lusts you, they'll wait... Hello! They'd wait for Beyonce, they can wait for you. 

6. The cliche of sexual sin. Whenever the devil wants to win a man's soul he pretty much always uses sex, money or both. Don't just be a walking, talking, breathing cliche...! 

7. 'Everybody is doing it so why shouldn't I?' There is nothing new about sexual sin under the sun. Christians are called to be 'peculiar people', i.e different [1 Peter 2:9], rather than take the broad easy road that leads to hell [Matthew 7:13]. Jesus was a revolutionary...Christianity is not for the yellow-bellied. 

8. Christianity either maintains, updates or does away with Jewish law (e.g. the Jewish dietary code is not applicable to Christians). Old Testament teaching of sexual sin (fornication or more broadly sexual immorality) being outside the will of God for mankind, is repeatedly maintained in the New Testament [Galatians 5:19, 1 Corinthians 5: 9-11]. 

9. Do not be deceived. If we are going to disregard sexual sin then we may as well disregard all other sins in Christianity. If there is 'no sin', what the heck did Jesus come to earth and die for??? 

10. Sexual Compatibility '101'. Whilst nobody ever built a 'whole relationship' off of sex alone, there is of course a place and purpose for it. Sex was designed by God to be something beautiful and binding between a husband & wife. What if you marry somebody and you're not sexually compatible? To become sexually compatible a husband and wife need to just find out what the other person likes and doesn't like, and to also realize that everyone has a learning curve. 

Thank God that that there is forgiveness and restoration at hand for anyone who repents. 

Repenting though is not the same as simply confessing or saying you're 'sorry'. The Greek root of the word 'repent' translates as 'turn away'. Yep that's a U-turn baby! 

We are largely responsible for what we consume from the media, be it online or other oulets. What we visually assimilate can influence our thoughts and our thoughts can influence our actions.

comment_text:
Interesting observation: Interviewer has not heard about "Idiot" nor "Inferno". I grew up in Eastern Europe. It was part of regular school literature. Only once i started living abroad i realised not many people have been introduced to classics in their high school. What a privilege.

It might be also useful sometimes  to have own interpretation of those classics then ponder on the derivative of it. Derivative of a derivative of a derivative can be very fragile...
author: @aleksandrajelicic5863

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Great comment. I've made the same observations. I'm from scandinavia and have often been annoyed by the insistence on local literature. When I was a teenager the libraries were full of real literature - and it's not like that any more. E
When I was 18 I had already  read Dostojevskij, Goethe, Nietzsche, Thomas Mann & Camus etc..
As I got older I was genuinely surprised that many people I knew had not had the same experience - as they simply didn't understand references, metaphors or allusions. A university professor once told me that in an ideal world the students in the humanities would have a basic knowledge of literature & philosophy - and speak at least 3-4 languages. In the world today that is simply impossible - students don't read more than absolutely necessary. 
The point is that mentioning "The Idiot or Inferno" in a conversation shouldn't need an explanation. Personally I blame social media and braindead tv.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
I've had several attempts to listen to end-to-end interviews of Jordan Peterson. But I've never been able to make it all the way through and despite your amazing interviewing skills, this one was no different.
I don't need to agree with him to listen, and there were many elements that I could agree with him. He presented great explanations to some questions - I especially loved the distinction between judge and condemn.

But there are points where I feel he speaks well to people who will be in agreement with him and he does a poor job at engaging people who may be open to listening but don't come in with the same opinion. I really struggled with him answering questions with "it's a complicated question," and "you need to read the book." 

It personally gave me a sense of him saying - "this is all too complicated for the average person to understand, and you should have a sense of faith in what he is saying without the element of building trust."
This is a shame, because I think that for those who are addicted to the ease of many trappings of modern life. They are probably not going to be convinced to step out of it by a premise that is all just a little bit too complicated.
author: @chasingwaterfalls8227

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: You need to watch it all then because thats not what he's saying. Life is complicated and simple edicts just wont cut it if you really want to understand and conquer your demons. Jordan can talk for literally hours just answering 1 simple question, but not all of it has to be of value to you personally so if he's directing you towards his book its likely because theres more depth in the book than he can be afforded in a 2 hour podcast.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
It is interesting that you interpreted “it’s a complicated question, read the book” as Jordan undermining the listener and wanting them to have blind trust. My interpretation was vastly different.  I appreciate you sharing your perspective, as it sparked me to question and think. I interpreted JP’s answer as a confirmation that “all or nothing thinking” is not a good idea (in this circumstance and any circumstances really). Often one believes in this AND this, AND this AND this,  it isn’t a question of either you believe in THIS or THAT, it can be a complex compilation of many truths and beliefs. It is very clear that JP believes in God/the highest value in the hierarchy of values/a construct or medium for human optimization. The specifics of what that exactly “looks like”shouldn’t really matter, it doesn’t change the goal.  Steven was asking specifically what form the god JP believed in took, possibly in hopes of being enlighten with a visual picture that SB could buy into as he wrestles with his own questions about God (like many).  It just really isn’t that simple, and not something JP is capable of making any more concise. Not only is there no real answer to this question (JP clarified that he derives his beliefs from what he has found evidence to be actually true), I don’t think Jordan has a “man up in the sky” specificity to his belief a higher power.  I understood from his answers that JP full heartedly believes there is a God/highest value in which he move towards, he knows it is absolutely  necessary to do so, he doesn’t think it is necessary to know exactly what form God takes in order to believe, and he continues to strive to explore truth’s to discover and share everything he learns on the subject. I personally like this more broad idea of a higher power, and hearing about JP’s deep dive into the biblical stories that have literally shaped our modern world.  This approach is very informative and comprehensible to me. The themes of these biblical stories recur throughout history, and presenting it to today’s society in this understandable and plausible way encourages people to come together for a greater good, to explore and realign our connection with others, drawing on values and faith, no matter what form one’s construct of a higher power takes. 
Jordan also said that he believed it is true that Jesus was God. I construed that based on JP’s knowledge of how Jesus conducted himself, the sacrifices and suffering he endured for his people, and his unwavering selflessness, was enough evidence for JP to place Jesus at a higher value than all other humans (aligning with his definition of God).
Thank you Steven Bartlett and Jordan Peterson for exploring your curiosities together on a public platform, because isn’t that the point of this thing called life? Go on the adventure, stay curious, aim high, and connect with others!
author: @kchapfinni

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Take what he says with a grain of salt. Peterson is dishonest in the way he presents his thoughts of studies, for example, as the right ones. He'll frame his interpretation like it's a fact. Right off the bat, he mentioned the cohabitation studies and how couples that live together before marriage have higher divorced rates. It's not the whole story! It wasn't the cohabitation that caused the failure, it was the intentions. Some moved in together, for example, not because or a shared set of values or worldview. The failed ones moved in for financial purposes, convenience, or pressure dynamics and marriage was seen as a logical next step, not a joyous milestone. If people DON'T cohabitate but get married for flimsy reasons, they're also likely to divorce. Nuance matters, and many times Peterson will ignore the nuance for the sake of vocalising his beliefs. Be very careful about references to studies and statistics, it's always better to read the primary source. Good luck!

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
Steven encounters the same issue all interviewers encounter when asking Jordan questions of faith: he doesn't want to get pinned into a clear and defined position. Peterson is a huge admirer of Jung, and Carl Jung said "you should all become Christs". But Jung was in his own words "beyond Christianity", because he studied comparative religion, esoteric traditions, and the occult. 

Peterson is basically trying formulate his own version of "the spirit of the depths", except instead of Isaac he's using Abraham as the figurehead of the dead ancestors, and because he's sold himself to the far right extremists he has to cram this ultimately Perennialist, quasi-Gnostic, largely Emanationist philosophy into the narrow confines of nu-traditional American Christianity. Except the right-wing, whose trying to rope in the lost ex-atheist redditors of the young milleu have to strip the fuzzy, mystical aspects out of it and try to present Christianity as more a of a practical philosophy towards life fulfillment and a script for life than an umcomfortably metaphysical religion. 

This is what saddens me, as Peterson started out, and could have continued, revealing some really useful wisdom and forgotten meaning to people -- but in my opinion its been corrupted by his political aims and his own barely masked rage. Search up what Gabor Mate has to say about him as a clinician. And if I were you, I'd be wary of listening to someone who calls the people he disagrees with "psychopathic narcissists" as a  psychologist, who self-describes himself firstly as a "trickster" figure. For someone so suspicious of "intellectual types" - he himself seems to portray a trickster persona with a penchant for flowery language and a lot of hot-takes on "taste" and what should and shouldn't be allowed in society with a kind of rigid, self-assured certainty he can't really justify beyond calling any other way "absurd".

At the very least, you should have had him explain it more clearly. If he is relying on the study I think he is, the more relevant factor was that the couples that divorced the least were couples in arranged marriages. And there are myriad cultural and personality factors that impact those divorce rates that do not apply to western couples. A more apples to apples study would be limited to couples in western societies who choose their own partner.

comment_text:
God as meaning. I don’t know about that. 

God has those qualities. But everything you think is meaningful, will not be. If you are wise, and diligent, you’ll figure out pretty quick whether you are right, but that’s not the whole of it.

God lays out his Word, so you can pursue him. His ways. And that brings meaning. That’s the testament of that. If you pursue something else and call it God. You bear the responsibility for that. 

That isn’t the pursuit of a sky daddy. That’s not the pursuit of something that bears the all characteristics it lays out. As an identity to be understood. As a relationship to be established. Who calls himself the creator of all. 

Take off the Sunday bumpers, and recognize whatever preconceptions you have about that thing are lacking. Its characteristics are vast and ineffable, and applicable in ways you just haven’t seen yet. And for all that, the profession is that those scriptures contain what is necessary for you to know him. 

Him. The characteristic and relationship he chose to associate to you with. A distinctly male identity. The paternal character of him, matters why? Lots of reasons. One is that he wanted to bring about a Son.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: Values-So many of the stories are about helping us understand ourselves, or human nature.  Values come from our NEED to live in cooperative community, as this is the strength of humanity, without which, we are weak and vulnerable.  So the stories teach the consequences of Pride, Greed, Sloth (includes self-pity) Envy, Wrath, Gluttony & Lust.  All of the sins are emotions or human impulses destructive of cooperative relationships.  So morality in civilization is the behavior necessary to preserve and promote the strength of civilization.  John Donne wrote “no man is an island” to remind us of the butterfly effect of our behavior on society and civilization.  We can’t survive as a culture or as a species as “rugged individuals;” even the most primitive of tribes live in cooperative groups.  The Christian tradition, as well as the stoic and Greek, teach self restraint, self control, self mastery in the face of nature, and acceptance of God as nature, fate and that which is beyond the control or choice of the individual.  Whether you believe in a man in the sky, or science, or in nothing, the fact is that we are a social species, dependent on one another, so avoiding those behaviors that lead to conflict helps strengthen both the individual and the community.  It’s the reason Machiavelli FEELS so wrong to most people.  He games human nature and manipulates for greed and power-behaviors that feel harmful to the trust that is the foundation of relationships.
author: @studynsleep

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
God didn’t make relationship with Him for only those with elite intelligence - so for anyone watching who feels confused by some of these answers and discussion points-  God is a real being- not a figment of our own construction, the gift of salvation is simple and it’s free to each of us if we’ll just say yes to it, and He’s not far away out of reach somewhere. He sees you and He really cares about you. 

I love a good intellectual discussion and do believe that the mysteries of God and His ways are deep and are actually endless- He’s infinite and yet we often think that we can contain Him fully in our human understanding (??)- BUT the depth of riches, of wisdom and knowledge of God does actually begin with some “simple” (straightforward) facts. It’s not all beyond our grasp or grandiose as it’s sometimes presented to be. He made the message of hope for us simple enough for us to grab onto yet still full of rich meaning for us to continue to explore.

There is God the Father, Jesus the Son who was/is fully God and fully man, and the Holy Spirit (the Trinity- 3 in 1). None of them were created by human consciousness- we are the created, He the Creator. And Jesus was a man, the only Son of God, who was sent to earth as the answer that God Himself provided to reconcile us to Himself again after the choice made in the garden of Eden separated us all from Him. Jesus lived a sinless human life and then chose to die to account for the sins of all of humanity- including mine and including yours- He broke the curse over us and conquered death, hell, and the grave! He really rose from the grave, it’s not just a concept. And He’s really coming back again. 

The reality we should be looking at is our current one where we each have to choose yes or no to receiving that gift of salvation, there is no neutral option. Jesus is the way, the truth, and the life and the only way to the Father is through Him. Just Jesus and what He did for us! Not through our intellect, not by being a good person or through any means other than becoming like a little kid in spirit by saying- I believe Jesus really came to earth as a man and He really died for me, and I really say yes to this gift of eternal life- to belong to God both now and forever.

The simplicity and depth available in the Bible and in relationship with the living God can satisfy and challenge any level of human intelligence. He holds the answers to all questions and mysteries that we can grasp within our human understanding and all the rest that supersede our capacity for understanding too. He’s alive and wants to connect with each of us right where we are and I love that about Him.
author: @annemosteller1850

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: @Alexalexalexalexx  putting in effort to make sure that we both feel safe and can express ourselves and be vulnerable with each other, which isn't an easy thing to do at all. I had difficulties talking about my feelings and opening up about my wants and need,  so I had to work on that part of mysel,  which helped with the relationship. That was a lot of work,  and I'm still working on it. We both had to learn to be active listeners too, like truly listen to each other. We started to ask each other how the other person was feeling or doing because we realized we were just going through the motions in life and a lot of our needs were not met. Out when there's issues we didn't take the time to bring it up because we were just moving on to next thing. So we started to ask those questions periodically. We also went to counseling. Just some of the things we did which all took effort and work and wasn't easy. At least to me, it felt difficult since i didn't grow up in a family that expressed their feelings very well. We were very emotional and after we explode we just move on like everything's fine without addressing any of the issues. There's other things too but i won't get into it. Just stuff that I learned as a child that didn't make relationships healthy so lots of unlearning which was a lot of work too. But all worth it.

comment_text: For me, I have mostly negative memories of my mother before her first schizophrenic episode. I was 3 and a half. I can’t control that and the trauma it caused. However, I can control my response to it and ensure that my children have a different story. My childhood was very traumatic. It ended with me though. video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: ​@wLBlue Jordan didn't say that his mother was perfect.  He said that he doesn't have a single bad memory of her.  There is a difference.  I am 60 years old.  My mom is 93, and is still doing very well cognitively for her age.  I visit and play cards with her for about six hours every other Sunday.  I would say the same thing about my mom as Jordan said about his.  I don't have a single bad memory of her.  I can't imagine that anyone would dislike her.  I have never seen or heard of her treating anyone poorly or in an unkind manner.  Of course, when I was young, she would discipline me and my brothers when we did not act appropriately, but that was done out of love and not anger.  I would never hold that against her.

comment_text:
@@juliaramoslobo109 So what are you suggesting then? If you don't want to change because you feel that "you are not being authentic, " you are looking at this incorrectly. 

When you grow and you want to survive and thrive, you will have to adapt. So, his suggestion of being the most desirable will undoubtedly fall into his suggestion. He suggests that whatever you change or control about yourself is a skill and value that you will only be able to acquire once you have mastered it. 

Can you change your height? You can't. Then you only change certain characteristics that were considered to be desirable to increase the probability. You will attract people who like the things you can offer. Your fashion sense can be tailored to your own sense of expression. Isn't that what you consider to be an individual choice or preference? The person or few people who show that they are attracted to you, did you choose them exactly? With an unlimited number of options or traits you may adapt, why would you think you may it is manipulative if you don't even know the person and their preferences? From no standard to a known standard that the opposite sex likes in a potential partner is a better suggestion than your skepticism.


I'm bothered by your skepticism and rush to judgment that he was lying. When you wrestle with a statement that someone says, try to dissect it before you conclude. When I came to a relationship with someone, I learned certain things about myself. I knew what desirable traits I wanted in a partner, and that changes as you grow older. I even learned that being passive with my ex-girlfriend with the negative characteristics would have been appropriately negotiated if I chose to speak up.
author: @NiWdLES

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
@ I don't think you understood my skepticism. 

My problem with his statement is the contradiction. He says he has a duty to speak only the truth, but then turns around and say that "In truth, you need to become more desirable by changing aspects of yourself if you want to attract someone."
So "do what I say, not what I do". He's proud of being honest, and then goes "don't be honest if you want to attract someone. You need to adapt to be desirable".

Here is where the problem lies: A lot of the red pill/black pill rhetoric generalize what women want in a partner as if women were a monolith, with no variety of thought, behavior, ideas, physical attraction and desire. 

They have a myoptic point of view of that women desire in a life partner, and put so much of their thought process into "cracking the code" of desirability, that they ignore simple life advice, which is: be a person that is genuine and not afraid to be their true self. 

With that, I'm not saying "never adapt" or "never change" as a person. Everyone has to change in order to adapt and survive. That's called growing up. Everyone has to adapt. For instance: You can't act in your work environment the same way you act among your friends and peers during a party. There are rules of conduct and you need to wear your "mask" of professionalism. You have to do this cuz your relationship with your job is transactional. You need to prove something in this environment, and the environment will grant you pay based on how well you prove it. 

The problem with red pill talking points, is that they transfer the transactional reality of the job market  into intimate relationships - putting "value" on individuals based on what they can "offer" in a relationship, pretty much as if they were employee and having an intimate/love relationship as if it's a job.

Here's what's wrong about this. Relationships take time and work, but they are not a job. As a person, you shouldn't approach a relationship as if you were an employee responding to an employer, or a boss addressing a subordinate. A romantic relationship should be a mutual equal bond, based on love, understanding, communication, and compatibility in many forms. That's why it takes a lot of time and work, cuz change and adaptability needs to come as the relationship progress. 

In order to attract someone, there is literally no "certain path" and anyone who tries selling this ( such as dating gurus and pick up artists ) are just selling a product they know will have a lot of deluded and desperate buyers. It's a fallacy. By following their advice, there's no guarantee you'll form any meaningful relationships or deep connections, cuz those are not transactional.

If all romance were transactional, rich people wouldn't divorce all the time, nor would they also be at risk of dying alone . If it was transactional, the conventionally attractive people with loads of money and a successful career, wouldn't feel lonely and lost. 

If you want to attract someone in particular, you shouldn't expect them to feel attracted to you in return. Projecting your desire onto others won't do anything other than frustrate you. Instead, if you want to change yourself, do it for your health and life balance. Do it to make you feel happy and love yourself. Do it to be a positive force in the world and those around you. Learn to love and value yourself. Impose respect without stepping on or disrespecting others. Become someone you feel genuine proud of. This is the hardest aspect of all of this.

A lot of people want to go into romantic relationships in order to redeem themselves. They want a relationship so they are not alone, so they feel loved, so they can feel complete, so they have someone to do things for them out of genuine care. But here's the thing. Everyone should strive to be a complete person, with their flaws and positive aspects. Everyone should strive to become better for themselves. 

The moment you change just to "Become desireable", you are betraying your own self growth. For instance, a lot of people act more loving, submissive, respectfully or hide their truth, just for their desired partner to lower their guard and trust them enough to stay in the relationship. Out of a sudden, when that relationship becomes too much of a high stake for the other partner to walk away from it, the masks of desirability worn by the one who hides their truth, crumble and the other partner is stuck with someone they didn't truly know. 

Thats what I'm criticizing here. I rather be in a relationship with someone with glaring flaws and self awareness, than someone who masked their true self just to become "desirable".
author: @juliaramoslobo109

At the end of the day, if you are seeking betterment just to make yourself "desireable", you aren't really becoming a better version of yourself. comment_text: @@GiaBao-gr2zd To me the whole "improve yourself" framing of the loneliness issue is talking past the larger problem.  The problem is that men have become more hesitant to approach women altogether — not because they don't want to, but because social expectations have changed. What used to be seen as confident or flirty is now often second-guessed out of concern for crossing boundaries. That might be a positive evolution in some ways, but it also creates a challenge in big cities where people rarely cross paths twice. Unlike small towns, where relationships can form naturally over time, urban life often requires a more direct approach to make connections. Ironically, just as that kind of boldness is becoming more necessary, men are being socially conditioned to hold back.

comment_text:
At 57:17 I realized Mr Peterson was done answering and started counseling the Host. I personally feel that an agreement is crucial for a relationship. Agreement that states the sharing of responsibilities. A guy should be responsible enough to provide for a partner's comfortable life and a girl should be responsible to support the guy and build him a family. Contract should state that if ever both parties due to whatsoever reasons, are not able to live together. In that case the contract can be terminated. This is the best way to show respect to a girl in an ideal society.
Responsible men make a better society. A man living with a partner, sharing life and depending on his partner without a contract is not a strong man. No doubt marriage is threatened in our societies by so many means but doing the right thing even when it's difficult is the beauty of a strong man. Brothers, we are men for a reason. God gave us more strength and brains to do so much more than just being equal to females. Men are supposed to go through the shit in the outside world and women need to make stronger societies.
The most respectful, loving, manly and dignified contract is the marriage contract.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text: I think the reason I find Jordan Peterson to be interesting is because we've arrived at similar conclusions on some ideas, but I find his path to reasoning very schizophrenic. He conflates terms in ways that feel misleading, like equating antisocial personality disorder (a clinical term for psychopathy) with simply not being social, or conflating being extroverted with being happy. He also uses a lot of absolute language like "evidence," "fact," "definition," and "non-disputable" to frame subjective concepts as if they're universally agreed upon. This manipulation of language forces connections between ideas that don’t logically align, all to neatly support his point. Above all, he takes ideas that anyone might find interesting and makes them so politically polarizing.

comment_text:
After many years of listening to JP there was one very dark time I was experiencing on one particularly differicult night I happened to have JP playing on my phone. 
Something genuinely, truly and deeply life...altering...thing shifted in my happened to me. 

Whiie I'm certainly not even close to the smartest person, even out on my own friend group, but I recognized early on that many mamy people seem to be OK with staying as aware as they'll ever get, as skilled as they'll ever be, as knowledgeable as that are as they'll ever get. I've never been like that. I've always been so curious about almost everything. I enjoy the adventure of seeking. 
In this way if seemed like people my own age thought I was a bit odd, while on the other hand much much older people seemed to get a kick out of a conversation with me. I heard as far back as I can remember hearing old timers say that I was "wise beyond my years". I think I just chalked it up to my curiosity. 

Anyway, since that night I've made many high stake decisions as in they outcome of making these choices would cause life to look very different than it had up til then. I moved to a different town, learned how to build a tiny home, allow myself to grapple with eating a mountains worth of humble pie, and also to create moments lf out quiet gratitude in the face of real challenges. I'm many of those vases I'm still very much elbows deep in in the journey. 

I've sat awake many nights contemplating writing a book, maybe a few, becoming a keynote speaker, sharing my stories, in the aim of encouraging others the seek and wrestle with God  (something I described about how I felt and how "it" feels looomg before JP was even publicly known) and unlock parts of their awareness. Selfishly, part of these daydreams leads me to a meaningful conversation between JP and myself. I know I'd get so much out of talking with him about so mamythings.

comment_text:
God is real. Even though you can’t see him doesn’t mean he isn’t real. Back in the day, it defied all logic that the earth was round. People were laughed at and discredited who thought otherwise, and yet current understanding did not lead to ultimate truth of reality. It wasn’t until hundreds of years later that the earth being indeed round not flat was truly proven to the world when the first spaceship launched into space and could actually get the perspective needed to see that the earth was in fact not flat, but actually round. Sometime we have to step out of our own biases and preconceived notions to find what is truly true. Sometimes we don’t want to find out what is true and stay in a place of uncertainty because finding out what is true is too scary. If there is actually a God then there really is a divine power that I may not understand everything about and if this God or divine power has indeed spoken to people “prophets” that have said what is right and what is wrong then I am accountable for trying to follow that divine law. Being in a place of constant uncertainty or indifference though brings its own set of challenges and limitations as well. 

There are so many things that testify that there is a divine creator. Just the miracle of life itself is a true wonder. Those who only recognize science and not God are failing to recognize that God IS the great scientist, He IS the creator. It’s the first thing He wants the world to know as that is the first thing we learn about Him in Genesis the first book in The Old Testament. 

I encourage all who don’t believe in God or don’t know if there is a God to seek to know for yourself by truly opening your heart to the reality that there actually is a God who is your loving Father in Heaven. We are his children and he loves us. And just as a father wants to communicate with his child, God wants to communicate with us, but He won’t force us to listen to Him. He waits for us us to reach out to Him through prayer, through studying His word in scripture, through seeking to serve others and taking time to quietly reflect and ponder so we can truly hear Him and be guided by His spirit.

Luckily I have met an amazing child who I adopted as my own. So I do get to experience what it’s like to be a mom and it’s glorious. I thought I didn’t want children yet here I am raising a kid and even though it’s challenging at times and I had to sacrifice so much: mainly my traveling nomadic nature, it’s been the biggest blessing in my life.

comment_text:
_"If each of us, citizens, had determined to assert his rights and dignity as a husband with respect to his own spouse, we should have less trouble with the sex as a whole; as it is, our liberty, destroyed at home by female violence, even here in the Forum is crushed and trodden underfoot, and because we have not kept them individually under control, we dread them collectively. But from no class is there not the greatest danger if you permit them meetings and gatherings and secret consultations."_

_"Our ancestors permitted no woman to conduct even personal business without a guardian to intervene in her behalf; they wished them to be under the control of fathers, brothers, husbands; we (Heaven help us!) allow them now even to interfere in public affairs, yes, and to visit the Forum and our informal and formal sessions. What else are they doing now on the streets and at the corners except urging the bill of the tribunes and voting for the repeal of the law?"_

_"Give loose rein to their uncontrollable nature and to this untamed creature and expect that they will themselves set no bounds to their license. Unless you act, this is the least of the things enjoined upon women by custom or law and to which they submit with a feeling of injustice. It is complete liberty or rather, if we wish to speak the truth, complete license that they desire."_

_"If they win in this, what will they not attempt? Review all the laws with which your forefathers restrained their license and made them subject to their husbands; even with all these bonds you can scarcely control them. What of this? If you suffer them to seize these bonds one by one and wrench themselves free and finally to be placed on a parity with their husbands, do you think you will be able to endure them? The moment they begin to be your equals, they will be your superiors."_

_"Now they publicly address other women’s husbands, and, what is more serious, they beg for a law and votes, and from various men they get what they ask. In matters affecting yourself, your property, your children, you, Sir, can be importuned; once the law has ceased to set a limit to your wife’s expenditures you will never set it yourself. comment_text: My father died on Friday and my mother died on Saturday.  I have been trying to find a way to grieve them both.  They were both 89 and did not die of a shared illness.  They were just synced to one another so closely that they died together.  I feel incredibly thankful for the tender mercy that neither will wake to find the other gone.  That gratitude overpowers other feelings of loss, even though those feelings are there and will certainly get stronger as I move into time.  God is real (yes, the man in the sky)l.  Eternal life is real.  Jesus Christ is our Saviour.  Without that knowledge nothing makes sense.  But I don't know these things through reason, I know them through the practice of prayer, faith and hope.  After practicing (as Jordan Peterson recommends) my belief is sure and no longer belief but knowledge.  God is truth, and truth is love.  Beautifully simple.  My parents are fine.  I will miss them but I know I will be with them again.  There is no knowledge greater than that. We are eternal.

comment_text:
One thing bothers me a lot with Peterson. I mean, besides all of my disagreements on the content.

For an academic, a practicioner, book author etc., he is very unclear in his view and his "philosophy" I guess, constantly seems like... random.
In comparison to other academics or scholars who are careful in their assumptions, axioms and foundations, who are careful in laying down the research they base their theory on, who basically are in conversation with academia, Peterson seems like a rambly bearded crazy wizard on a hill.

He is just going on on those long convoluted explanations, often approximating and saying things that are simply either not true, or definitely not that clear cut as he says, and bases those metaphysical theories on top...

Social sciences are not an art project. It requires rigor. That here is not rigorous.

video_title: Jordan B Peterson: You Need To Listen To Your Wife! We've Built A Lonely & Sexless Society!
comment_text:
“What God do you believe in?” I know this is a question so many struggle with, and I’ve had interesting conversations with friends of various faiths about this same question. Please never give up your personal search- it is worth the effort!

I do believe in God, who is Heavenly Father and Heavenly Mother together loving us eternally and doing the best for their children (all of humanity), while respecting our freedom to choose- which is why bad things happen to good people,often as the result of our own or others’ choices. Our Heavenly Parents have immortal bodies of flesh, which we will all have once we’re resurrected- a gift all will receive through Christ’s atonement. We’re here so we can grow and learn in ways we never could if we remained with them. This requires not only learning to choose good, to be humble and think of others first, but also experiencing pain (physical & emotional), hardship, failure, trials, etc. Natural disasters and circumstances not caused by our own or others’ choices cause us to go through pain and loss while also being humbled, coming together, looking to God for comfort, and thinking of others. Pain and suffering due to the poor choices of others or our own poor choices helps us remember to reach for God and our Savior Jesus Christ, who’s very familiar with that pain, and to learn how to forgive and help others in similar circumstances. 

One of the greatest paths to learning is through family relationships. This is why marriage was ordained by God. Just as you wouldn’t likely start a business relationship or rent your property without a contract, joining with another person and creating a family is best done with a covenant/promise between the two. That marriage and family can, if desired, continue in the eternities. The work we do on these relationships is worthwhile and not all for naught. We will be helped and blessed as we strive to love others as God and Christ do. 

We can and will return to our heavenly home with our Heavenly Parents and Jesus Christ one day. Hopefully in the meantime we will grow and learn to fulfill the measure of our creation. There is absolute, eternal truth. The search for and recognition of it brings unimaginable joy and peace. Know that the source of that truth is God, and you can turn to Him in prayer asking for guidance. There is nothing He wants more than to help you in your search, though like any good teacher, He won’t just immediately give you all the answers. Keep searching it out for yourself and listen to the promptings you receive- He will guide you. I wish you all the best in your journey.
